original_query: How can I compare the metrics for different periods?
rewritten_query: How can I compare the metrics for different periods?
agent_response: You can compare the metrics for different periods using the Time period control in the user interface. This control allows you to choose the period for which data is displayed, and it affects all data shown on the page, including the graph, statistics, and lists of top intents and entities. You can choose to view data for a single day, a week, a month, or a quarter, and the data points on the graph will adjust to an appropriate measurement period. Additionally, you can create custom time periods, such as a week that runs from Thursday to the following Wednesday, or a month that begins on any date other than the first.

Here's the classification of the last user utterance and its reworded version: ```json {"class": "non-standalone", "reworded version": "Examples of custom time periods, please."} ``` However, since your question refers to the immediate context of creating custom time periods, I would recommend the following standalone version: ```json {"class": "standalone", "reworded version": "Examples of custom time periods, please."} ```.
agent_response:
Sure, here are some examples of alerts you can create using the system:

1. Slack alert: You can set up an alert to be sent to a Slack channel when there are more than 100 instances of a specific error message in a given hour. To do this, you would specify the Webhook URL for your Slack channel and the desired Message color.

2. Email alert: You can configure an alert to be sent to a specific email address when the number of log entries for a particular application exceeds a certain threshold. For this type of alert, you would specify the Recipients' email addresses and the Timezone for the log entries.

3. PagerDuty alert: You can create an alert that triggers a PagerDuty incident when a critical error occurs in your system. To do this, you would specify the PagerDuty Service that should be notified.

4. Webhook alert: You can set up an alert to be sent to a custom webhook when a specific condition is met. For this type of alert, you would specify the Method, URL, and Headers and Body of the JSON used to interact with your webhook.

In each case, you can also customize the schedule for the alert, specifying the timezone, days of the week, and timeframe when the alert should be generated. This allows you to limit alerting to specific times, reducing noise and ensuring that you are notified only when necessary.

rewritten_query: Can you explain more about how I can work with metrics?
agent_response:
A metric is a quantitative measure that has one or more labels to define its characteristics. It is represented by time series, which is a unique combination of a metric name and label key-value pairs. Metrics can be used to analyze statistically data that has numerical values and can help identify and differentiate characteristics of a metric, such as grouping infrastructure objects into logical hierarchies, filtering out data, and splitting aggregated data into segments.

There are various platforms and orchestrators where metrics can be collected, including Prometheus, JMX, StatsD, Kubernetes, and other application stacks. Default metrics can be collected using the Monitoring agent, which automatically collects metadata that can be used to label, segment, and display metrics when monitoring infrastructure, network, and applications.

To compare metrics for different periods, you can use the Time period control in the user interface to choose the period for which data is displayed. This affects all data shown on the page, including the graph, statistics, and lists of top intents and entities. You can view data for a single day, a week, a month, or a quarter, and create custom time periods as well.

I hope this helps clarify your understanding of metrics. If you have any further questions, I'd be happy to help!

The document does not provide specific information about billing based on the number of turns or conversations.

rewritten_query: How can I perform filtering of metrics?
agent_response:
To filter custom metrics in a Monitoring agent, you can customize the metrics\_filter section in the agent configuration file. You can specify which metrics to include and which ones to filter out by configuring the include and exclude filtering parameters.

Here's an example of how you can configure the metrics\_filter section:

metrics\_filter:
- include: metricA.
- exclude: metricA.
- include: metricB.
- include: haproxy.backend.
- exclude: haproxy.
- exclude: metricC.

In this example, the monitoring agent is configured to collect all data from metrics that start with metricA, metricB, and haproxy.backend, while filtering out metrics that start with metricC and other metrics that start with haproxy.

Note that the filtering rule order is set as follows: the first rule that matches a metric is applied, and follow-up rules for that metric are ignored.

For more information, you can refer to the following resources:

* Linux Monitoring agent: <https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/monitoring?topic=monitoring-change_linux_agentchange_linux_agent_inc_exc_metrics>
* Kubernetes Monitoring agent: <https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/monitoring?topic=monitoring-change_kube_agentchange_kube_agent_inc_exc_metrics>
* Docker container Monitoring agent: <https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/monitoring?topic=monitoring-change_agentparams>

original_query: What are the advantages and disadvantages of Immutable data Storage?
rewritten_query: What are the advantages and disadvantages of Immutable data Storage?
agent_response:
Based on the provided document, I can provide some points about Immutable Object Storage, which is a type of Immutable data Storage.

Advantages:
1. Data Integrity: Immutable Object Storage maintains data integrity in a WORM (Write-Once-Read-Many) manner. This means that objects can't be modified until the end of their retention period and the removal of any legal holds.
2. Long-term Data Retention: This feature can be used by any user that needs long-term data retention in their environment. It's particularly useful for organizations in industries like Financial, Healthcare, and Media content archives.
3. Legal Compliance: Retention policies can also be used by organizations that deal with financial records management, such as broker-dealer transactions, and might need to store data in a non-rewritable and non-erasable format.

Disadvantages:
1. Regional Availability: Immutable Object Storage is available in certain regions only.
2. Pricing: It requires a Standard pricing plan.
3. No High-speed Transfer: It isn't possible to use Aspera high-speed transfer with buckets with a retention policy.
4. No Automatic Deletion: There's no automatic deletion of files once the retention period expires. You would need to manually manage this.

Please note that these points are based on the information provided in the document. The actual advantages and disadvantages may vary based on the specific use case and requirements.

rewritten_query: Can you tell me more about what a Lite account is in IBM Cloud?
agent_response: A Lite account in IBM Cloud is a free account type that never expires. It allows you to create one instance of any service in the IBM Cloud catalog that has a Lite plan. For more information, see [Account types](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/account?topic=account-accountsliteaccount).

rewritten_query: How can I create a Lite pricing plan account in IBM Cloud?
agent_response:
To create a Lite account in IBM Cloud, you can follow these steps:
1. Go to the IBM Cloud website and click on the "Create an account" button.
2. Fill out the registration form with your email address, password, and country.
3. Leave the credit card information blank, as a Lite account does not require a credit card.
4. Agree to the terms and conditions and click on the "Create account" button.
5. You will receive a confirmation email. Click on the link in the email to verify your account.

After creating the account, you can access the IBM Cloud catalog and create one instance of any service that has a Lite plan.

Note: If you created a Lite account before 12 August 2021, you have access to 186 GBH of free buildpacks and Cloud Foundry apps with up to 256 MB of free instantaneous runtime memory per month. However, after 30 days of no development activity, your service instances with Lite plans are deleted.

For more information, see [Account types](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/account?topic=account-accountsliteaccount).

rewritten_query: What is the monthly usage limit in megabytes for a Lite account?
agent_response:
If you have a Lite account in IBM Cloud and created it before 12 August 2021, you can build and deploy apps with 256 MB of instantaneous runtime memory. However, if you exceed the 1 GB storage limit in the Lite plan, IBM Cloudant will block your account from writing new data until you delete enough data to be under the 1-GB limit, or upgrade to a higher plan.

For the Standard plan, the first 20 GB of storage comes free, and any storage over the 20 GB limit costs $0.0014 per GB per hour, which is approximately $1 per GB per month.

It's important to note that the Lite account has limitations and is not meant for production workloads. It is recommended to upgrade to a Pay-As-You-Go or Subscription account for more flexibility and higher capacity.

If you have specific usage requirements, you can check the usage data in the IBM Cloud Dashboard by going to Manage > Billing and usage > Usage. Here you can see the total charges and usage for the month by service, plan, or instance. Only the hourly costs that are accrued for the current month and time are available. At the end of the month, you can see the average provisioned throughput capacity for each field: LOOKUPS_PER_MONTH, WRITES_PER_MONTH, and QUERIES_PER_MONTH.

rewritten_query: Can you provide support for my account creation process?
agent_response: IBM Cloud provides technical support for Lite accounts with free support through the IBM Cloud docs and Stack Overflow. By default, account users don't have access to create, update, search, or view cases, and the account owner must provide users access by assigning an Identity and Access Management (IAM) access policy. To create a support case, you can follow the steps outlined in the document, including selecting the category for your issue, completing the required fields, and attaching files if necessary. However, do not include any personal information, sensitive data, or device or service credentials in case responses. You can also choose to receive support case notifications by email. After your support case is created, you can follow its progress on the Manage cases page. For more information, see [Assigning user access for working with support cases](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/get-support?topic=get-support-accessaccess) and [Creating a support case](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/get-support?topic=get-support-createcase).

original_query: I cannot get select query to work, what steps should I take?
rewritten_query: I cannot get select query to work, what steps should I take?
agent_response:
I'm sorry to hear that you're having trouble with your SELECT query. Here are some general steps you can take to troubleshoot the issue:

1. **Check your syntax**: Make sure your query is correctly formatted and that all keywords, table names, and column names are spelled correctly. 

2. **Check your access permissions**: Ensure that you have the necessary permissions to access the tables and columns specified in your query. 

3. **Check your input data**: If your query involves input data from IBM Cloud Object Storage, make sure the data is in the correct format and that you've specified the correct delimiter, if necessary. 

4. **Check your output location**: Make sure you have specified a valid location to store the results of your query.

5. **Check for errors**: If there are any error messages, they can provide clues as to what's going wrong. 

If you're still having trouble, you may want to refer to the Data Engine documentation or the IBM Cloud SQL Query documentation for more detailed instructions and examples.

rewritten_query: How can I improve my query formation?
agent_response:
To improve your query, you can consider the following steps:

1. **Optimize your query**: Review your query to ensure it's as efficient as possible. Avoid using the "SELECT *" statement and instead specify the exact columns you need. Use indexes to improve query performance.

2. **Refine your query**: If your query is returning too many or too few results, you may need to refine it. You can do this by adding or modifying the WHERE clause to include more specific conditions.

3. **Test your query**: Test your query with different inputs and data sets to ensure it works as expected. This can help you identify any issues or limitations with your query.

4. **Consider using a different query type**: If your current query type isn't providing the desired results, consider using a different type of query. For example, if you're using a SELECT statement, you might consider using a JOIN statement instead.

5. **Use query optimization tools**: Many database management systems offer tools that can help you optimize your queries. These tools can analyze your query and provide suggestions for improving its performance.

If you're using IBM Watson Discovery, you can improve your query by providing more training data, adding a custom stopwords list, or adjusting the confidence score threshold.

rewritten_query: Could you provide more information about the API for creating queries?
agent_response:
I'd be happy to provide more details about query APIs, but it seems that the document only provides information about the Data Engine service REST API in the context of IBM Cloud. This API allows you to run SQL queries and retrieve information about their status. However, since you mentioned "query API" in general, I'll provide a brief overview.

A query API is an application programming interface that enables you to retrieve, manipulate, and update data stored in a database or a data store by sending HTTP requests. Query APIs usually support various HTTP methods (like GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) to interact with data and return the results in a structured format (commonly JSON or XML).

The specifics of a query API depend on the underlying data store and the API implementation. However, most query APIs support CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations and may offer additional features like filtering, sorting, pagination, and querying based on specific conditions.

For instance, if you're using IBM Watson Discovery, its Query API allows you to search and analyze your data using a powerful query language designed for unstructured content. You can find more information about the IBM Watson Discovery Query API in the following documentation: <https://cloud.ibm.com/apidocs/discovery-data?curl=#query-api>

Keep in mind that the specifics of the query API you use will depend on the data store and platform you're working with. If you provide more context or details about the query API you're interested in, I can give a more targeted answer.

rewritten_query: Can I address my storage space limits? How can I add or delete storage?
agent_response:
Yes, you can address storage space limits in several ways. First, you can free up space by deleting unnecessary data such as old snapshots, unused models, and model versions. If you have a Premium or Standard account in Knowledge Studio, you can also set a storage limit on the Service Details page to manage your monthly bill.

To add storage, you can consider upgrading your plan to one that provides a larger allotment of storage space. The specific steps to add or delete storage may vary depending on the platform or service you are using. For instance, if you are using IBM Cloud Object Storage, you can add or remove storage by managing your buckets and the objects within them. If you provide more details about the specific platform or service you are using, I can give a more targeted answer.

rewritten_query: Could you explain what Data Lakes are?
agent_response: A data lake is an approach to storing data in its native format for organizational use. It involves storing raw data in a centralized repository, such as Object Storage, where it can be accessed and analyzed by data analysts using Structured Query Language (SQL) and services like Data Engine. This allows for data to be queried where it lies, reducing the need for data movement and transformation. Data lakes can be used to store various types of data, including big data and streaming data, and can be refined and analyzed for various purposes, such as business intelligence and machine learning.

rewritten_query: Could you please explain how to create a schema or tables?
agent_response:
To create a schema or tables in IBM Watsonx.data, follow these steps:

1. Log in to the Watsonx.data console.
2. From the navigation menu, select Data manager.
3. Select the engine from the Engine drop-down. Catalogs that are associated with the selected engine are listed.
4. Select a schema under a catalog where you want to import a file to create table.
5. Click the overflow menu of the selected schema and select Create table from a file. The Create table from a file page opens.
6. Follow the steps in the Creating tables topic to complete importing the file.

If you want to create a table in a specific schema, ensure that you have selected the schema before clicking the overflow menu.

Alternatively, you can create a table directly in a database using IBM Cloud SQL Query by following these steps:

1. Go to Databases.
2. Select the database in which you want to create a table.
3. Select the schema in which you want to create a table.
4. Ensure that you are in the DB Objects > Tables tab.
5. Click Create table.
6. Type a name for the table and specify the columns, data types, and other properties.

Remember that the table name is case-preserving, so use uppercase to match database defaults. The dot character (".") is not supported in the table name.

rewritten_query: Use IBM Cloudant Query.
agent_response:
Sure, I can provide more information about using IBM Cloudant Query.

IBM Cloudant Query is a powerful query language built on Apache Lucene that allows you to perform complex searches and aggregations on your IBM Cloudant data. It supports a wide range of query types, including full-text search, numeric range queries, and faceted navigation.

To use IBM Cloudant Query, you first need to create a design document that defines the indexes you want to use for your query. A design document is a JSON document that contains one or more index definitions, as well as any query functions or views that you want to use.

Once you have created a design document, you can use the _search endpoint to execute queries against the indexes defined in your design document. The _search endpoint supports several parameters, including the index name, the query string, and the include_docs parameter, which allows you to include the full document in the query results.

Here's an example of a query that uses IBM Cloudant Query to search for documents with a specific author and year:

GET /$DATABASE/_design/$DDOC/_search/$INDEX\_NAME?include\_docs=true&query="author:\"Dickens\" AND year:1840" HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/json
Host: $ACCOUNT.cloudant.com

In this example, the query string "author:\"Dickens\" AND year:1840" searches for documents where the author field is equal to "Dickens" and the year field is equal to 1840. The include\_docs parameter is set to true, so the full document is included in the query results.

You can also use the IBM Cloudant Query API to execute queries programmatically from your application. The API supports several programming languages, including Java, Node, Python, and Go.

I hope that helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.

rewritten_query: What does Vulnerability Advisor scan and what is its actual function?
agent_response:
Vulnerability Advisor scans container images for security issues and potential vulnerabilities. When you add an image to a namespace in IBM Cloud Container Registry, the image is automatically scanned by Vulnerability Advisor. If security issues are found, instructions are provided to help fix the reported vulnerability. However, it's important to note that Vulnerability Advisor does not scan encrypted images, as stated in the document.

Additionally, Vulnerability Advisor generates a security status report that includes suggested fixes and best practices. It's available in two versions: version 3 and version 4, with version 4 using new architecture and a different scanning engine. Version 3 is deprecated from 19 June 2023.

The scan results can help you to secure your IBM Cloud infrastructure by fixing the reported security and configuration issues. You can monitor vulnerabilities that are detected by Vulnerability Advisor using IBM Cloud Security and Compliance Center.

Please note that Using Portieris to block the deployment of images with issues that are found by Vulnerability Advisor is deprecated.

This information can be found in the document under the "Data protection" section.
Then what does Vulnerability Advisor scan? what does it actually do?
Vulnerability Advisor scans container images for security issues and potential vulnerabilities.
When you add an image to a namespace in IBM Cloud Container Registry, the image is automatically scanned by Vulnerability Advisor.
If security issues are found, instructions are provided to help fix the reported vulnerability.
However, it's important to note that Vulnerability Advisor does not scan encrypted images, as stated in the document.
Additionally, Vulnerability Advisor generates a security status report that includes suggested fixes and best practices.
It's available in two versions: version 3 and version 4, with version 4 using new architecture and a different scanning engine.
Version 3 is deprecated from 19 June 2023.
The scan results can help you to secure your IBM Cloud infrastructure by fixing the reported security and configuration issues.
You can monitor vulnerabilities that are detected by Vulnerability Advisor using IBM Cloud Security and Compliance Center.
Please note that Using Portieris to block the deployment of images with issues that are found by Vulnerability Advisor is deprecated.
I currently have Vulnerability Advisor version 3...
If you currently have Vulnerability Advisor version 3, you should update to version 4 by 19 June 2023.
Version 4 uses new architecture and a different scanning engine, which provides enhanced features and improvements.

You can find more information on how to update to version 4 in the document [Update Vulnerability Advisor to version 4 by 19 June 2023](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/Registry?topic=Registry-registry_notices_va_v4&interface=ui).
how can I get this Vulnerability Advisor v4?
To get Vulnerability Advisor v4, you can update to the latest version of the Container Registry plug-in, which includes the availability of Vulnerability Advisor v4.

You can find more information on how to update in the document [Vulnerability Advisor 4 is available from Container Registry plug-in 1.0.0](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/Registry?topic=Registry-registry_release_notes15sep2022_va_version_4).
However, please note that the document does not provide specific instructions on how to upgrade to Vulnerability Advisor v4.
It is recommended to consult the official IBM Cloud documentation or contact IBM support for detailed instructions on upgrading.

rewritten_query: What is the difference between Vulnerability Advisor version 3 and version 4?
agent_response:
Vulnerability Advisor version 4 differs from version 3 in several ways:

1. Architecture: Version 4 uses new architecture that provides enhanced features and improvements over version 3.
2. Scanning Engine: Version 4 utilizes a different scanning engine compared to version 3.
3. IBM Cloud Console: If you use the IBM Cloud console to access Vulnerability Advisor, no action is required as it is automatically updated to version 4.
4. IBM Cloud CLI: If you use the IBM Cloud CLI, you must update the Container Registry CLI plug-in to version 1.0.0 or later by 19 June 2023, so that the ibmcloud cr va command and the --va option on the ibmcloud cr images and ibmcloud cr digests commands work with Vulnerability Advisor version 4.
5. REST API and SDKs: If you use the Vulnerability Advisor REST API or one of the Vulnerability Advisor version 3 SDKs to access Vulnerability Advisor, you must update to the Vulnerability Advisor version 4 SDK or update your client call from /va/api/v3 APIs to /va/api/v4 APIs.

For more information about updating to version 4, refer to the document [Update Vulnerability Advisor to version 4 by 19 June 2023](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/Registry?topic=Registry-registry_notices_va_v4&interface=ui).

rewritten_query: What if I want to create encrypted image, given Vulnerability Advisor can't scan encrypted images?
agent_response:
Even though Vulnerability Advisor cannot scan encrypted images, you can still create encrypted images for other purposes such as protecting sensitive data. To create an encrypted image, you can use various tools and techniques, such as Docker's built-in encryption feature or third-party tools like `cryptsetup` or `dm-crypt`. However, keep in mind that encrypted images are not scanned by Vulnerability Advisor, so you will not be able to detect any security issues in them using this tool.

Here is an example of how to create an encrypted image using Docker's built-in encryption:

1. Create a new image based on a secure base image (e.g., `ubuntu:latest`).
2. Add any necessary files or applications to the image.
3. Commit the changes to the image.
4. Encrypt the image using the `docker commit` command with the `--encrypt` option.
5. Push the encrypted image to a secure registry.

Here is an example command to create an encrypted image:
```sql
$ docker commit --encrypt my_image my_encrypted_image
```
In this example, `my_image` is the name of the original image, and `my_encrypted_image` is the name of the new encrypted image.

Note that encrypted images may have some limitations, such as increased storage requirements and slower performance, so you should consider these factors before deciding to encrypt your images.

rewritten_query: Can you clarify the IBM Cloud® Container Registry you are mentioning here?
agent_response: IBM Cloud® Container Registry is a managed service provided by IBM that offers a multi-tenant, highly available, scalable, and encrypted private image registry for storing and accessing container images. It is hosted and managed by IBM, and is integrated with the Security and Compliance Center to help manage security and compliance for your organization. It is a required service for using Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud. For more information, see [IBM Cloud Container Registry](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/Registry?topic=Registry-getting-started).

what is difference between Vulnerability Advisor version 3 and version 4?

Vulnerability Advisor version 4 differs from version 3 in several ways:

1.
Architecture: Version 4 uses new architecture that provides enhanced features and improvements over version 3.
Scanning Engine: Version 4 utilizes a different scanning engine compared to version 3.
IBM Cloud Console: If you use the IBM Cloud console to access Vulnerability Advisor, no action is required as it is automatically updated to version 4.

IBM Cloud CLI: If you use the IBM Cloud CLI, you must update the Container Registry CLI plug-in to version 1.0.0 or later by 19 June 2023, so that the ibmcloud cr va command and the --va option on the ibmcloud cr images and ibmcloud cr digests commands work with Vulnerability Advisor version 4.

REST API and SDKs: If you use the Vulnerability Advisor REST API or one of the Vulnerability Advisor version 3 SDKs to access Vulnerability Advisor, you must update to the Vulnerability Advisor version 4 SDK or update your client call from /va/api/v3 APIs to /va/api/v4 APIs.

For more information about updating to version 4, refer to the document [Update Vulnerability Advisor to version 4 by 19 June 2023](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/Registry?topic=Registry-registry_notices_va_v4&interface=ui).
What if I want to create encrypted image since Vulnerability Advisor can not scan it?
Even though Vulnerability Advisor cannot scan encrypted images, you can still create encrypted images for other purposes such as protecting sensitive data.
To create an encrypted image, you can use various tools and techniques, such as Docker's built-in encryption feature or third-party tools like `cryptsetup` or `dm-crypt`.
However, keep in mind that encrypted images are not scanned by Vulnerability Advisor, so you will not be able to detect any security issues in them using this tool.

Here is an example of how to create an encrypted image using Docker's built-in encryption:

1.
Create a new image based on a secure base image (e.g., `ubuntu:latest`).
Add any necessary files or applications to the image.
Commit the changes to the image.
Encrypt the image using the `docker commit` command with the `--encrypt` option.
Push the encrypted image to a secure registry.

Here is an example command to create an encrypted image:
```sql
$ docker commit --encrypt my_image my_encrypted_image
```
In this example, `my_image` is the name of the original image, and `my_encrypted_image` is the name of the new encrypted image.
Note that encrypted images may have some limitations, such as increased storage requirements and slower performance, so you should consider these factors before deciding to encrypt your images.

rewritten_query: Can you clarify how to set up namespaces?
agent_response:
A namespace in the context of the IBM Cloud Container Registry is a way to divide up cluster resources. To set up a namespace, you can follow the steps in the document titled "[Set up a namespace](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/Registry?topic=Registry-getting-startedgs_registry_namespace_add)".

In summary, you can use the `ibmcloud cr namespace-add` command followed by the name of the new namespace to create a namespace. The name of the namespace must meet certain requirements, such as being unique across all IBM Cloud accounts in the same region, having 4-30 characters, starting and ending with a letter or number, and containing only lowercase letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores.

Once you have created a namespace, you can configure access to resources within that namespace at the resource group level by assigning the namespace to a resource group. You can use the `ibmcloud cr namespace-assign` command followed by the name of the namespace and the name or ID of the resource group to assign a namespace to a resource group.

It is important to note that if you have the Manager role at the account level, you can add or remove namespaces. However, if you don't have the Manager role, you may need to request access from an administrator.

If you are unsure about whether a namespace is already set up for your account, you can run the `ibmcloud cr namespace-list` command with the `-v` option to retrieve existing namespace information.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.

original_query: Is Red Hat Virtualization the same as Red Hat OpenShift virtualization?
rewritten_query: Is Red Hat Virtualization the same as Red Hat OpenShift virtualization?
agent_response: Based on the provided documents, Red Hat Virtualization and Red Hat OpenShift virtualization are not the same. Red Hat Virtualization is a complete virtualization management solution for servers and applications, while Red Hat OpenShift virtualization (also known as container-native virtualization) is a feature that allows OpenShift to orchestrate containerized workloads alongside virtual machine workloads. The Red Hat OpenShift virtualization is not supported by IBM for virtual machine workloads on their Cloud, and it requires bare metal machines instead.

rewritten_query: What is Red Hat OpenShift?
agent_response:
Based on the provided documents, Red Hat OpenShift is a Kubernetes container platform that provides a trusted environment to run enterprise workloads. It extends the Kubernetes platform with built-in software to enhance app lifecycle development, operations, and security. With Red Hat OpenShift, you can consistently deploy your workloads across hybrid cloud providers and environments. It is designed to work with containerized applications and provides additional features to improve the development, operations, and security of these applications.

rewritten_query: What are the benefits of using Red Hat OpenShift?
agent_response:
Based on the provided document, Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud offers several benefits including:

* A choice of container platform provider - you can deploy clusters with Red Hat OpenShift or community Kubernetes installed as the container platform orchestrator.
* A choice of developer experience - you can choose the developer experience that fits your company, or run workloads across both Red Hat OpenShift or community Kubernetes clusters.
* Built-in integrations from the IBM Cloud console to the Kubernetes dashboard or Red Hat OpenShift web console.
* A single view and management experience of all your Red Hat OpenShift or community Kubernetes clusters from IBM Cloud.

Additionally, with Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud, your developers have a fast and secure way to containerize and deploy enterprise workloads in Kubernetes clusters. Your Red Hat OpenShift workloads can scale across IBM’s global footprint of data centers and multizone regions. You’re able to uniformly monitor, log, and secure apps. IBM manages the service, so you can focus on innovating with high-value IBM Cloud services and middleware, such as AI and analytics. You also have access to Red Hat packaged open-source tools, including your favorite app runtimes, frameworks, databases, and more.

rewritten_query: Is the use of scripts necessary?
agent_response: Based on the provided documents, the necessity of scripts depends on the specific requirements of your continuous integration and continuous deployment strategies. Custom scripts are extension points in the pipeline where adopters, teams, and users can provide scripts to run custom tasks that are required by their strategies. However, if the default scripts provided in the commons library meet your needs, you may not need to create additional scripts. These default scripts perform tasks such as iterating over assets, running scans/check jobs, and collecting evidence. You can customize these stages in your pipeline config if needed.

original_query: Should we switch to a different method for installing the mobile SDK, considering the current approach's limitations?
rewritten_query: Should we switch to a different method for installing the mobile SDK, considering the current approach's limitations?
agent_response:
Based on the information provided, the mobile SDK for IBM Cloud Functions can be installed using CocoaPods, Carthage, or from the source directory. If you're encountering issues with the current approach, you might consider switching to a different method.

For instance, you could use CocoaPods, which is a public distribution method for the IBM Cloud Functions SDK for mobile. Here's a snippet from the document showing how to set up a Podfile for this purpose:

```ruby
install! 'cocoapods', :deterministic_uuids => false
use_frameworks!

target 'MyApp' do
pod 'OpenWhisk', :git => 'https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-client-swift.git', :tag => '0.3.0'
end

target 'MyApp WatchKit Extension' do
pod 'OpenWhisk', :git => 'https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-client-swift.git', :tag => '0.3.0'
end
```

After setting up the Podfile, you can install the SDK by running `pod install` from the command line. Then, use the workspace file CocoaPods creates for your app to open the project in Xcode.

Keep in mind that there might be a warning about configuring the Swift version when building the project. In such a case, you can use the [Edit > Convert > To Current Swift Syntax…] menu to choose a Swift version or configure the build setting directly.

If this method doesn't suit your needs, you could consider the other available options, such as installing with Carthage or from the source directory. More information on these methods can be found in the provided documents.

rewritten_query: I asked about a source code example.
agent_response:
Sure, here's an example of how you can use the IBM Cloud Functions mobile SDK in your source code:

1. First, you need to set up a Podfile for IBM Cloud Functions SDK by adding the following lines:

```ruby
install! 'cocoapods', :deterministic_uuids => false
use_frameworks!

target 'MyApp' do
pod 'OpenWhisk', :git => 'https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-client-swift.git', :tag => '0.3.0'
end

target 'MyApp WatchKit Extension' do
pod 'OpenWhisk', :git => 'https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-client-swift.git', :tag => '0.3.0'
end
```

2. Then, install the SDK by running `pod install` from the command line.

3. After the installation, you can import the OpenWhisk framework in your Xcode project:

```swift
import OpenWhisk
```

4. Here is an example code snippet that uses the IBM Cloud Functions SDK to invoke a simple action:

```swift
import OpenWhisk

// Initialize the OpenWhisk client
let openWhisk = OpenWhiskClient()

// Set the authentication credentials
openWhisk.authorization = Authorization(apikey: "<your_api_key>")

// Define the action parameters
let params = [
    "input": "Hello, World!"
] as [String : Any]

// Invoke the action
openWhisk.actions.invoke("hello", parameters: params) { (response, error) in
    if let response = response {
        print(response.result)
    } else if let error = error {
        print(error.localizedDescription)
    }
}
```

Replace `<your_api_key>` with your actual IBM Cloud Functions API key. This is an example of code that you can use to invoke an action. You can modify and expand this code to fit your needs.

rewritten_query: Can I configure the IBM Cloud Functions mobile SDK to work with different installations of Cloud Functions?
agent_response:
Yes, you can configure the IBM Cloud Functions mobile SDK to work with different installations of Cloud Functions by using the baseURL parameter. By default, the mobile SDK uses the instance that is running at [https://us-south.functions.cloud.ibm.com](https://us-south.functions.cloud.ibm.com). However, you can specify a different baseURL to connect to a different Cloud Functions installation. For example, you can use the following code to set the baseURL to a local installation running at <http://localhost:8080>:

```swift
whisk.baseURL = "http://localhost:8080"
```

This way, you can use the mobile SDK to interact with different Cloud Functions installations as needed.

For instance, if you're using CocoaPods and encountering version issues, you might try using Carthage or installing from the source directory instead. However, please note that the IBM Cloud Functions SDK for mobile is only officially available for distribution through CocoaPods. If you decide to use Carthage or install from the source directory, you might not receive official support or updates. Therefore, it's important to weigh the benefits and drawbacks of each method before making a decision.

rewritten_query: What about the potential issues when installing with CocoaPods?
agent_response:
If you're encountering issues with installing the mobile SDK using CocoaPods, you might consider the following alternatives:

1. **Carthage**: This is a dependency manager that can be used to install the IBM Cloud Functions SDK. You would need to add the following line to your Cartfile: `github "openwhisk/openwhisk-client-swift.git" > 0.3.0 Or latest version`. After running `carthage update --platform ios`, you need to add the `OpenWhisk.framework` file to the embedded frameworks in your Xcode project.

2. **Installing from source code**: This involves downloading the source code from GitHub, opening the project with Xcode, and building the schemes. This gives you more control over the build process but requires more manual work.

However, please note that if you choose to use Carthage or install from the source directory, you might not receive official support or updates. Therefore, it's important to consider the trade-offs before switching.

rewritten_query: When using CocoaPods for installation, there is a warning that appears.
agent_response:
If you're encountering a warning when installing the IBM Cloud Functions SDK with CocoaPods, it might be about the Swift version. This warning is caused if CocoaPods does not update the Swift version in the Pods project. To fix this, you can select the Pods project and the IBM Cloud Functions target, go to Build Settings, and change the setting Use Legacy Swift Language Version to no. Alternatively, you can add the following post installation instructions at the end of your Podfile:

```ruby
post_install do installer
installer.pods_project.targets.each do target
target.build_configurations.each do config
config.build_settings['SWIFT_VERSION'] = '4.0'
end
end
end
```

Replace '4.0' with your required Swift version. After adding this to your Podfile, run `pod install` again. This should resolve the warning and configure the correct Swift version for your targets.

rewritten_query: What are the instructions to do it using Carthage?
agent_response:
Sure, here are the instructions to install the IBM Cloud Functions SDK using Carthage:

1. Create a file in the project directory for your app and name it `Cartfile`.
2. Put the following line in the file: `github "openwhisk/openwhisk-client-swift.git" > 0.3.0 Or latest version`
3. From the command line, type `carthage update --platform ios`. Carthage will download and build the SDK, create a directory that is called `Carthage` in the project directory for your app, and put an `OpenWhisk.framework` file inside `Carthage/build/iOS`.
4. Add the `OpenWhisk.framework` file to the embedded frameworks in your Xcode project.

Remember, if you choose to use Carthage, you might not receive official support or updates. Therefore, it's important to consider the trade-offs before switching.

rewritten_query: Could you provide more information about the WebSocket API?
agent_response:
The WebSocket API is a protocol that enables real-time, two-way communication between a client and a server. It is used in the Text to Speech service on IBM Cloud to send two types of parameters: query parameters and message parameters.

Query parameters are sent when the phone integration connects to the service and are used to specify how the data should be searched and filtered. They typically include information such as the access token for authentication, the voice synthesis settings, and any other options for customizing the service.

Message parameters, on the other hand, are sent as part of the JSON data in the request body and are used to control the behavior of the service during a conversation. For example, you can use message parameters to specify the voice that the assistant should use, to enable or disable speech barge-in, or to transfer a call to a live agent.

For more information about the WebSocket API and its parameters, you can refer to the Text to Speech API documentation on IBM Cloud. It is also worth noting that if the socket closes with an error, the client will receive an informative message of the form {"error":"{message}"} before the socket closes. You can use the onerror event handler to respond appropriately.

I hope this information is helpful! If you have any other questions, please don't hesitate to ask.

rewritten_query: How can I use WebSocket API?
agent_response:
To use the WebSocket API, you first need to establish a connection with the service using the /v1/synthesize method over the WebSocket Secure (WSS) protocol. The method should be called at the following endpoint: wss://api.{location}.text-to-speech.watson.cloud.ibm.com/instances/{instance\_id}/v1/synthesize where {location} indicates where your application is hosted and {instance\_id} is the unique identifier of the service instance.

Once the connection is established, you can send text and binary messages over the connection to initiate and manage recognition requests. The WebSocket interface is the preferred mechanism for speech recognition due to its advantages. For more information about the WebSocket interface and its parameters, you can refer to the API & SDK reference on IBM Cloud.

For client-side entities like mobile apps, an API call fetches the current configuration state when a user opens the app or brings it to the foreground. If you need more sophisticated monitoring, you can create an IBM Cloud Monitoring instance from the Observability section of the IBM Cloud console.

For more information about App Configuration cost, you can use the IBM Cloud Cost Estimator tool or refer to the guidelines for predicting cost in detail. The Application Instance cost is a fixed monthly cost, while the Active Entity ID cost is based on the number of unique entities that interact with your App Configuration instance during the month.

If you have any other questions or need more specific information, feel free to ask!

rewritten_query: I want to secure the phone connection before the integration.
agent_response:
To secure the phone connection before the integration, you can follow these steps:

1. Go to the Advanced options tab in the phone integration settings.
2. Select one or both of the following options for added security:
a. Force secure trunking: This option uses Secure Real-Time Transfer Protocol (SRTP) to secure the audio transmitted over the phone.
b. Enable SIP authentication: This option requires SIP digest authentication for inbound traffic and must be sent using Transport Layer Security (TLS). If this option is selected, you will need to configure the SIP digest user name, password, and set up the SIP trunk to use only TLS.

Please note that if you use Twilio as your SIP trunk provider, you cannot enable SIP authentication for outbound SIP trunks to Watson Assistant.

For more information about RTP, you can refer to the Call routing details documentation. If you need further assistance, don't hesitate to ask.

rewritten_query: What are the limits on the number of phone numbers I can have for interaction?
agent_response:
Yes, there are limits to the number of phone numbers you can use for interaction. If you are using existing phone numbers that you configured via a SIP trunk provider, you can add multiple numbers to the same phone integration. However, if you generated a free phone number, you cannot add more numbers. The limit for uploading a set of phone numbers via a CSV file is not specified in the document, but it is mentioned that the phone numbers you upload will replace any existing numbers in the table.

Additionally, it's important to note that any speech service charges incurred by the phone integration are included as Voice add-on charges in your Watson Assistant service plan usage. The Voice add-on use is charged separately and in addition to your service plan charges. The number of concurrent calls that your assistant can participate in at one time depends on your plan type. The Enterprise plan allows for 1,000 concurrent calls.

rewritten_query: What if I have call and transfer failures, requiring the use of other third-party providers?
agent_response:
If you experience call and transfer failures and need to use third-party providers, you can configure the phone integration to transfer the caller to a human agent if the phone connection fails for any reason. You can specify the SIP endpoint for your support agent service or a general call queue that can redirect requests to other queues in the SIP target when a call fails field. Additionally, you can configure a message for the assistant to say to a caller before it transfers the call to a human agent, as well as a message for when transfer to a live agent fails. If you choose to leave a call connected despite a transfer failure, Watson Assistant will initiate a new turn to determine the next step.

However, if you want to use third-party providers for disaster recovery, you may need to configure two separate SIP trunks, one for each region, and only switch the call to the backup region when all the zones in a single region fail. It's important to set the SIP INVITE failure timeouts at the SIP trunking provider low enough to avoid long call setup latencies when a failover is occurring.

If you need to handle partial service outages, Watson Assistant can respond to a SIP INVITE with a SIP 500 (service unavailable) message if an outage is detected during call setup instead of transferring a call to a live agent. This can be used to redirect the call to another zone or another region. You can request this 500 error response capability for a specific Watson Assistant instance from IBM.

It's also recommended to plan for both full and partial service outages, starting with a manual failover between regions before enabling automation. This requires a complete replica of Watson Assistant in both regions, including all custom speech model training. After this is in place, a strategy can be implemented to deal with partial outages, which should cover the vast majority of failure conditions that can occur with a phone integration deployment.

original_query: Is Dynamic secret better than Static secret?
rewritten_query: Is Dynamic secret better than Static secret?
agent_response: The documents do not provide a direct comparison between dynamic and static secrets in terms of which one is better. Instead, they describe the differences between the two types of secrets and their use cases. Dynamic secrets are identified by programmatic name, such as iam\_credentials, and their expiration date and time are enforced when their secret data is read or accessed. They are suitable for accessing IBM Cloud services that require IAM authentication. On the other hand, static secrets, such as arbitrary secrets and username\_password, have their expiration date and time enforced at secret creation or rotation time. They are suitable for storing arbitrary pieces of sensitive data, including any type of structured or unstructured data, that you can use to access an application or resource. Ultimately, the choice between dynamic and static secrets depends on the specific requirements of your use case.

rewritten_query: Are there serverless instances?
agent_response: Yes, there are serverless instances in the context of IBM Analytics Engine. These instances allow you to spin up Apache Spark clusters as needed and customize the Spark runtime and default Spark configuration options. The details of a serverless instance, such as the instance ID (or GUID) and the provisioning state, can be retrieved using the IBM Cloud CLI or the IBM Cloud REST API. Each Analytics Engine instance is associated with an IBM Cloud Object Storage instance for instance-related data accessible by all applications that run in the instance.

rewritten_query: Could you explain what Spark is?
agent_response: Apache Spark is an open-source, distributed computing system used for big data processing and analytics. It provides an interface for programming entire clusters with implicit data parallelism and fault tolerance. Spark supports a wide range of tools, libraries, and programming languages, including Python, Scala, R, and SQL. It can process various data formats, such as structured, semi-structured, and unstructured data. Spark can be used for various use cases, such as batch processing, real-time data streaming, machine learning, and graph processing. It can also integrate with other big data tools, such as Hadoop, Apache Hive, and Apache HBase. Spark offers a web-based user interface (Spark UI) that helps users monitor and track the performance of their Spark applications.

rewritten_query: What about the Hive metastore client?
agent_response: The Hive metastore client is a component that allows Apache Spark to interact with the Hive metastore server, which stores metadata related to Hive tables and partitions. By using the Hive metastore client, Spark can access and manage Hive tables and partitions, as well as perform tasks like query optimization and data serialization. The Hive metastore client is typically used in scenarios where Spark is integrated with Hive, such as when using Spark SQL or DataFrames to query Hive data. The client can be configured with various parameters, such as the Hive metastore URI, SSL settings, authentication mode, and user credentials.

original_query: Can you summarize the differences between good bots and bad bots?

agent_response: Good bots perform helpful services such as customer service chatbots, search engine crawlers, and performance monitoring bots. Bad bots do not follow the rules set out in the robots.txt file.

rewritten_query: Could you tell me about the features of a bot that follows the rules outlined in a website's robots.txt file?
agent_response: IBM Cloud Internet Services (CIS) bot features include JavaScript detections using Google’s Picasso fingerprinting technique. This technique gathers general data about the machines reaching CIS and helps CIS classify traffic as automated or human. It only injects a small amount of JavaScript into client devices for requests for HTML pages or page views, excluding AJAX calls and affecting API and mobile app traffic. The Picasso script is roughly 70 KB and execution time varies by device. The snippets of JavaScript will contain a source pointing to the challenge platform with paths that start with /cdn-cgi/challenge-platform/.... JavaScript detections are automatically enabled for no-cost Trial plans (Bot Fight Mode) and optional for all other plans. To ensure that visitors have previously run and passed JavaScript detections, you can create a firewall rule with the field cf.bot_management.js_detection.passed which performs a Managed Challenge action. If you have a Content Security Policy (CSP), ensure that anything under /cdn-cgi/challenge-platform/ is allowed.

rewritten_query: How does CIS manage bots?
agent_response: IBM Cloud® Internet Services (CIS) manages bots by collecting data from requests flowing through its network every day. With this data, powered by Cloudflare's machine learning and behavior analysis, CIS can identify likely bot activity and can provide you with information on how to allow or disallow specific bot traffic using Firewall Rules. CIS uses JavaScript detections, which inject a small amount of JavaScript into client devices for requests for HTML pages or page views, excluding AJAX calls. This helps CIS classify traffic as automated or human. JavaScript detections are automatically enabled for no-cost Trial plans (Bot Fight Mode) and optional for all other plans. To ensure that visitors have previously run and passed JavaScript detections, you can create a firewall rule with the field cf.bot_management.js_detection.passed which performs a Managed Challenge action. If you have a Content Security Policy (CSP), ensure that anything under /cdn-cgi/challenge-platform/ is allowed.

rewritten_query: Update models for machine learning is what the user is asking about.
agent_response:
To update machine learning models, you can follow these steps:

1. Log in to the CIS and select your account and domain.
2. Go to Security > Bots.
3. Select Configure Bot Management.
4. Enable auto-updates to the machine learning model.

Enabling auto-updates for the machine learning model upgrades you to the latest version immediately. You can toggle the button off within 24 hours to revert to the previous version. To make changes after 24 hours, you may need to contact support. If you are on an older machine learning model, you'll see a score change to requests scored by the machine learning source instantly. If you are already on the latest model, the changes show only after a new machine learning model becomes the global default. You will be notified prior to a new machine learning model becoming the global default.

rewritten_query: Create a machine learning model, how is that done?
agent_response:
Yes, you can create a machine learning model in IBM Watson Knowledge Studio or IBM Watson Knowledge Studio for IBM Cloud Pak for Data. Here are the general steps to create a machine learning model:

1. Log in as a Knowledge Studio administrator and select your workspace.
2. Select Machine Learning Model > Performance.
3. Verify that all of the document sets have been approved and that all annotation conflicts have been resolved through adjudication. Only documents that have become ground truth through adjudication or approval can be used to train the model.
4. Click Train and evaluate to train the model and evaluate annotations added by the machine learning model, or click Train to train the model only.
5. Select the document sets that you want to use for training the model.

The exact steps may vary depending on the specific platform you are using. It's also important to note that training a machine learning model can take several minutes or several hours, depending on the number of human annotations and the total number of words across all documents.

Can I create a machine learning model and how should I do that?
Yes, you can create a machine learning model in IBM Watson Knowledge Studio or IBM Watson Knowledge Studio for IBM Cloud Pak for Data.

Here are the general steps to create a machine learning model:

1.
Log in as a Knowledge Studio administrator and select your workspace.
Select Machine Learning Model > Performance.
Verify that all of the document sets have been approved and that all annotation conflicts have been resolved through adjudication.

Click Train and evaluate to train the model and evaluate annotations added by the machine learning model, or click Train to train the model only.
Select the document sets that you want to use for training the model.
The exact steps may vary depending on the specific platform you are using.

rewritten_query: What is a secret?
agent_response: A secret is a piece of sensitive information, such as an API key or password, that is used to access confidential systems or services. Secrets allow entities to communicate and perform actions on a service by providing identification and a set of permissions. They should be securely generated, stored, and managed through their entire lifecycle, and never stored in source code, configuration files, or documentation.

What are the features in the CIS bot?
IBM Cloud Internet Services (CIS) bot features include JavaScript detections using Google’s Picasso fingerprinting technique.
This technique gathers general data about the machines reaching CIS and helps CIS classify traffic as automated or human.
It only injects a small amount of JavaScript into client devices for requests for HTML pages or page views, excluding AJAX calls and affecting API and mobile app traffic.
The Picasso script is roughly 70 KB and execution time varies by device.

The snippets of JavaScript will contain a source pointing to the challenge platform with paths that start with /cdn-cgi/challenge-platform/.... JavaScript detections are automatically enabled for no-cost Trial plans (Bot Fight Mode) and optional for all other plans.

To ensure that visitors have previously run and passed JavaScript detections, you can create a firewall rule with the field cf.bot_management.js_detection.passed which performs a Managed Challenge action.
If you have a Content Security Policy (CSP), ensure that anything under /cdn-cgi/challenge-platform/ is allowed.

IBM Cloud® Internet Services (CIS) manages bots by collecting data from requests flowing through its network every day.

rewritten_query: How can I protect my privacy?
agent_response:
Protecting your privacy involves several steps, including:

1. Avoid storing personal data as metadata for your keys. This includes information such as your name, location, or any other personally identifiable information (PII).
2. When adding keys to a service, avoid entering PII.
3. Ensure that any key material meets the specified requirements, such as being base64-encoded and no larger than 7,500 bytes for a standard key.
4. Consider enabling the EU Supported setting for your IBM Cloud account if you are processing personal data for European citizens in the Frankfurt, Germany region.
5. Enable two-factor authentication (2FA) on your accounts whenever possible.
6. Never store secrets, such as API keys or passwords, in source code, configuration files, or documentation. Instead, use a secure secret management solution.
7. Regularly update your software and systems to ensure that you have the latest security patches and updates installed.

By following these steps, you can help protect your privacy and minimize the risk of unauthorized access to your sensitive information.

original_query: How do I build my client application using dialogue nodes?
rewritten_query: How do I build my client application using dialogue nodes?
agent_response:
To build your client application using dialogue nodes, you can follow the provided document and complete the tutorials that build more advanced dialogs. Here are the steps:

1. Complete the follow-on tutorials that build more advanced dialogs, such as adding standard nodes with the "Building a complex dialog" tutorial and learning about slots with the "Adding a node with slots" tutorial.
2. Add more dialog nodes to design complex conversational exchanges (see Building a complex dialog).
3. Learn techniques for getting customers to share information that the assistant needs before it can provide a useful response (see Adding a node with slots).
4. Integrate the assistant with websites or channels, such as Slack, that your customers already use.
5. As traffic increases between the assistant and your customers, use the tools that are provided in the Analytics page to analyze real conversations and identify areas for improvement.

Keep in mind that the assistant should be polished before integrating it with your client application. Also, make sure to have an account for the IBM Cloud Platform, Docker, Node.js, and Git installed, as they are required to build and deploy the application.

rewritten_query: You mentioned worker nodes in the context of this conversation, but they haven't been explained in the prior part. Could you clarify what worker nodes are?
agent_response: Worker nodes in the context of IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service are the virtual machines that your cluster manages. These worker nodes and all their components are dedicated to you only and are not shared with other IBM customers. However, the underlying hardware is shared with other IBM customers. Worker nodes include components such as the kubelet, kube-proxy, and container runtime, among others. They are responsible for running your workloads and carrying the deployments and services that make up your app. For more information, you can refer to the provided document on worker node components.

rewritten_query: What are VPC clusters?
agent_response: Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) clusters in the context of IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service are clusters that run in your own dedicated virtual network. This network is isolated from other virtual networks, which provides an additional layer of security for your applications and services. VPC clusters allow you to have fine-grained control over your network architecture, including subnets, IP ranges, and network policies. This is particularly useful for applications that require a high level of security and isolation, such as those used by financial institutions or healthcare providers. For more information, you can refer to the IBM Cloud documentation on VPC clusters.

rewritten_query: How to create a cluster?
agent_response:
To create a cluster in IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service, you need to follow these steps:

1. Prepare your account to create clusters by creating a billable account, setting up an API key with infrastructure permissions, making sure that you have Administrator access in IBM Cloud IAM, planning resource groups, and setting up account networking.
2. Decide on your cluster setup by planning cluster network and HA setup, estimating costs, and if applicable, allowing network traffic through a firewall.
3. Create your VPC Gen2 or classic cluster by following the steps in the IBM Cloud console or CLI.

For more information, you can refer to the IBM Cloud documentation on creating clusters.

rewritten_query: And what is the charge for VPC?
agent_response: Pricing for VPC infrastructure varies based on regional location and sustained usage. For VPC worker nodes, when you create a cluster on VPC infrastructure, the worker nodes might incur an uplift charge that varies by the multizone location that you create the cluster in. The uplift charge is a percentage (%) of the hourly rate (r), and is added to the hourly rate of the worker node. The total hourly rate cost for a worker node can be calculated as r + (r × %). For more information on the pricing uplift by region, see [Regional pricing for VPC](https://cloud.ibm.com/vpc-ext/provision/vs). Additionally, for virtual server instances that are billed at an hourly rate, discounted prices depend on how long the instance runs during the billing month.

rewritten_query: Is storage included in the VPC price?
agent_response: Storage is not included in the VPC price. Block Storage for VPC volumes is priced separately and set by region. For more information on Block Storage pricing, see [Pricing](https://www.ibm.com/cloud/vpc/pricing).

original_query: How do cloud computing security protocols evolve over time, and what are the potential implications for restoring volumes from backup snapshots in IBM Cloud VPC?
rewritten_query: How do cloud computing security protocols evolve over time, and what are the potential implications for restoring volumes from backup snapshots in IBM Cloud VPC?
agent_response:
The documents provided do not contain information on how cloud computing security protocols evolve over time. However, they do provide information on restoring volumes from backup snapshots in IBM Cloud VPC. 

Restoring a volume from a backup snapshot in IBM Cloud VPC creates a new, fully provisioned boot or data volume. This process can be done during instance creation, instance modification, or when you provision a new stand-alone volume. For data volumes, you can also use the volumes API to create a data volume from a snapshot. 

For best performance, you can enable snapshots for fast restore. This feature allows you to create a volume from a snapshot that is fully provisioned when the volume is created. 

It's important to note that restoring a volume from a backup snapshot may result in degraded performance in the beginning, as the data is copied from IBM Cloud Object Storage to Block Storage for VPC. 

You can also copy a backup snapshot from one region to another region for disaster recovery scenarios. The cross-regional copy can be used to turn on your virtual server instance and data volumes in a different region. 

The fast restore feature allows you to cache snapshots in a specified zone of your choosing, which enables volumes to be restored from snapshots nearly immediately and the new volumes to operate with full IOPS instantly. 

When using fast restore, the data is pulled from a cached backup snapshot in another zone of your VPC. 

Cost for backups is calculated based on GB capacity that is stored per month. The backup exists on the account until it reaches its retention period, or when you delete it manually, or when you reach the end of a billing cycle, whichever comes first. 

Pricing of subsequent backups can increase or decrease when you adjust IOPS by specifying a different IOPS profile for the source volume. Billing for an updated volume is automatically updated to add the prorated difference of the new price to the current billing cycle. 

Pricing for backups is also set by region of the source volume. 

Using the backup service, you can regularly back up your volume data based on a schedule that you set up. You can create backup snapshots as frequently as 1 hour. You can also create copies of your backup snapshot in other regions. However, the backup service does not provide continual backup with automatic failover

rewritten_query: Could you tell me more about Data Encryption?
agent_response: Data encryption is a method of converting data into a code to prevent unauthorized access. It uses a two-way function to transform data into a form that hides its original value, but can be converted back to the original state. This process often involves the use of encryption keys to encrypt and decrypt the data. Data encryption can be used to protect data in transit, such as when data is sent over a network, or to protect data at rest, such as when data is stored on a physical drive.

rewritten_query: Is data encryption the same as data backup and disaster recovery?
agent_response:
No, data encryption, data backup, and disaster recovery are different concepts related to data protection.

Data encryption is the process of converting data into a code to prevent unauthorized access, while data backup is the process of creating a duplicate copy of data to protect against data loss or corruption. Disaster recovery is the process of restoring data and systems after a catastrophic event, such as a natural disaster, hardware failure, or cyber attack.

While data encryption can be a component of data backup and disaster recovery strategies, it is not the same as these processes. Data encryption is focused on protecting data from unauthorized access, while data backup and disaster recovery are focused on protecting data from loss or corruption and restoring it to a functional state after an incident.

rewritten_query: Could you tell me about the different types of clouds?
agent_response:
The documents provided describe three different types of clouds: public, private, and hybrid.

A public cloud includes a shared set of resources that are provisioned to allow access to a company's resources. It is hosted in a multi-tenant environment on a virtual server, and it can be accessed from anywhere.

A private cloud includes resources that are provisioned to allow access to a company's resources. It is hosted on dedicated hardware, such as a bare metal server, and either onsite at the company's office (or across offices) or by a cloud provider. A private cloud can be accessed from anywhere.

A hybrid cloud includes resources that combine the aspects of both public and private clouds. It is hosted both onsite at a company's office (or across offices) and by a cloud provider. A hybrid cloud can be accessed from anywhere.

In addition, the documents provide metadata for classifying attributes related to cloud resources, such as Cloud Type, Location, Resource, Resource Type, and Scope. There are also additional attributes available for segmenting these metrics, such as Service instance, Service instance name, and Resource group.

rewritten_query: What are the benefits of these mentioned concepts or processes?
agent_response:
The benefits of using cloud computing, as described in the documents, include:

1. Cost Savings: Cloud computing allows for cost savings by eliminating the need for physical infrastructure, reducing energy consumption, and minimizing the need for on-site maintenance.

2. Scalability: Cloud computing resources can be quickly and easily scaled up or down as needed, allowing for flexibility in response to changing business needs.

3. Accessibility: Cloud computing resources can be accessed from anywhere, at any time, and on any device, enabling remote work and collaboration.

4. Reliability: Cloud computing providers offer service level agreements (SLAs) that guarantee a certain level of availability and reliability, reducing the risk of downtime.

5. Security: Cloud computing providers offer robust security measures, including data encryption, access controls, and regular backups, to protect data and systems.

6. Innovation: Cloud computing enables faster innovation by providing access to new technologies and services, allowing businesses to stay competitive and respond quickly to changing market conditions.

7. Sustainability: Cloud computing can help reduce the carbon footprint of businesses by reducing the need for physical infrastructure and centralizing resources.

8. Disaster Recovery: Cloud computing can help improve disaster recovery capabilities by providing off-site backups and enabling quick restoration of data and systems in the event of a disaster.

9. Collaboration: Cloud computing enables real-time collaboration and sharing of data and applications, improving productivity and communication within teams.

10. Agility: Cloud computing allows for rapid deployment of new applications and services, enabling businesses to quickly respond to changing market conditions and customer needs.

original_query: how can I estimate my costs?
rewritten_query: how can I estimate my costs?
agent_response:
To estimate your costs in IBM Cloud, you can use the cost estimator tool. Here are the steps to follow:

1. Go to the IBM Cloud console and click on the Cost estimator icon.
2. Click on 'Create new estimate' and enter a name and description for your estimate.
3. Click 'Create' and you will be directed to the estimate details page.
4. Click on 'Go to catalog' to add products to the estimate.
5. Select the product that you are interested in and click 'Add to estimate'.
6. Enter your estimated usage and click 'Calculate Cost'.

Keep in mind that some charges, such as costs for your underlying infrastructure, may not be reflected in the estimate. Also, if you need to estimate costs for a different location or currency, you may need to select the appropriate currency on the order summary page or change the currency on your account.

Additionally, when you create a resource like a location or cluster, you can review a cost estimate in the Summary pane of the console. You can also view and control your current usage by visiting the relevant IBM Cloud documentation.

rewritten_query: Could you explain the differences between Fixed, Metered, Tiered, and Reserved?
agent_response:
Sure, I'd be happy to explain the differences between Fixed, Metered, Tiered, and Reserved pricing models:

1. Fixed: Fixed-rate pricing is based on an agreed-upon monthly charge that isn't adjusted, regardless of usage. This pricing model is typically used for services with predictable usage or flat-rate services.

2. Metered: Metered-usage pricing is based on the number of GB hours that are consumed for runtimes and the number of IP addresses and storage for containers. It's a usage-based pricing model, where you pay for what you consume.

3. Tiered: Tiered pricing is based on a tiered pricing model, so you can get a volume-based discount according to your actual usage. Services might offer simple, graduated, or block tier pricing plans, with the price decreasing as the usage increases. This pricing model is typically used for charge metrics that are expected to have high quantities per month, such as API calls.

4. Reserved: Reserved pricing is based on a long-term commitment for a service, so you can get a discounted price. With a reserved plan, you get a dedicated service instance that is easy to set up, deploy, and deliver in the public IBM Cloud environment. This pricing model is typically used for services where you can make a long-term commitment, such as Db2 on Cloud.

It's important to understand the pricing structure of the specific services you are utilizing to ensure accurate cost estimation and control.

rewritten_query: What is the process of managing my payments?
agent_response:
To manage your payments in IBM Cloud, you can use the [Payments](https://cloud.ibm.com/billing/payments) page in the IBM Cloud console or go to [IBM® Billing](https://myibm.ibm.com/billing/). A valid credit card is required for all Pay-As-You-Go and Subscription accounts. Every month, the credit card is charged with the usage amount that is accumulated during that month. When updates to your payment details are approved, they are applied to your account within 24 hours. You can contact IBM Cloud Support to get help with payment-related issues.

Before managing payments, you need to be assigned the operator role or higher on the billing account management service. If you manage your payment method on a separate billing platform, you can easily register, update, or delete a payment method by going to [IBM Billing](https://myibm.ibm.com/billing/).

For more information about managing your payments, see [Managing your payment method](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/billing-usage?topic=billing-usage-linkedusageprereqs-payments).

rewritten_query: Can you show me how to view my invoices and their status?
agent_response:
To view your invoices in IBM Cloud, you can follow these steps:

1. Go to the [Invoices](https://cloud.ibm.com/billing/invoices) page in the IBM Cloud console.
2. Here, you can check the status of your invoice. The possible statuses are:
	* Invoiced: You received the latest invoice from IBM Cloud.
	* Paid: Your payment for the charges on your latest invoice was received.
	* Unpaid: The charges on your latest invoice have not been paid.
	* Pending: Your payment for your latest charges has not been applied due to a payment processing error.
3. You can also view and download your invoice from the IBM console by clicking the Download icon next to each invoice. For some accounts, invoices are available through the [Invoices@IBM](http://ibm.com/invoices) website.

If your invoices are managed through the IBM Invoices website, the invoice is paid when the status is Settled.
