Click 'Create' and you will be directed to the estimate details page.
Click on 'Go to catalog' to add products to the estimate.
Select the product that you are interested in and click 'Add to estimate'.
Enter your estimated usage and click 'Calculate Cost'.
Keep in mind that some charges, such as costs for your underlying infrastructure, may not be reflected in the estimate.
Also, if you need to estimate costs for a different location or currency, you may need to select the appropriate currency on the order summary page or change the currency on your account.
Additionally, when you create a resource like a location or cluster, you can review a cost estimate in the Summary pane of the console.
You can also view and control your current usage by visiting the relevant IBM Cloud documentation.
are there different types of charges I am charged?
Yes, there are different types of charges that you might incur when using IBM Cloud services.
Some charges are directly related to the specific service instance that you create in your Satellite location, while others are associated with the underlying infrastructure.
The costs for your underlying infrastructure might not be reflected in the initial cost estimate that you review in the Summary pane of the console.

For more details regarding the charges associated with Satellite-enabled IBM Cloud services, you can refer to the [Supported Satellite-enabled IBM Cloud services](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/satellite?topic=satellite-managed-services) documentation.

Furthermore, the [Estimating your costs](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/billing-usage?topic=billing-usage-costcost) documentation offers guidance on estimating costs for different types of services and resources.
In general, it's essential to understand your usage patterns and the pricing structure of the specific services you are utilizing to ensure accurate cost estimation and control.
can you tell me the difference among Fixed, Metered, Tiered, and Reserved?
Fixed: Fixed-rate pricing is based on an agreed-upon monthly charge that isn't adjusted, regardless of usage.
This pricing model is typically used for services with predictable usage or flat-rate services.
Metered: Metered-usage pricing is based on the number of GB hours that are consumed for runtimes and the number of IP addresses and storage for containers.
It's a usage-based pricing model, where you pay for what you consume.
Tiered: Tiered pricing is based on a tiered pricing model, so you can get a volume-based discount according to your actual usage.
Services might offer simple, graduated, or block tier pricing plans, with the price decreasing as the usage increases.
This pricing model is typically used for charge metrics that are expected to have high quantities per month, such as API calls.
Reserved: Reserved pricing is based on a long-term commitment for a service, so you can get a discounted price.
With a reserved plan, you get a dedicated service instance that is easy to set up, deploy, and deliver in the public IBM Cloud environment.
This pricing model is typically used for services where you can make a long-term commitment, such as Db2 on Cloud.
It's important to understand the pricing structure of the specific services you are utilizing to ensure accurate cost estimation and control.
am I charged for those support costs as well?
Yes, support costs are also charged separately in IBM Cloud.
The cost of support is not included in the charges for other services and resources.
You can track your monthly support costs from the Support costs page in the IBM Cloud console.
Charges for support are based on your resource usage, with a minimum monthly price for providing support at the stated service level.
For more information about your purchased support plan, you can contact IBM Cloud Sales.
what is the process of managing my payments?
To manage your payments in IBM Cloud, you can use the [Payments](https://cloud.ibm.com/billing/payments) page in the IBM Cloud console or go to [IBM® Billing](https://myibm.ibm.com/billing/).
A valid credit card is required for all Pay-As-You-Go and Subscription accounts.
Every month, the credit card is charged with the usage amount that is accumulated during that month.
When updates to your payment details are approved, they are applied to your account within 24 hours.
You can contact IBM Cloud Support to get help with payment-related issues.
Before managing payments, you need to be assigned the operator role or higher on the billing account management service.
If you manage your payment method on a separate billing platform, you can easily register, update, or delete a payment method by going to [IBM Billing](https://myibm.ibm.com/billing/).
For more information about managing your payments, see [Managing your payment method](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/billing-usage?topic=billing-usage-linkedusageprereqs-payments).
view my invoices and status

To view your invoices in IBM Cloud, you can follow these steps:

1.
Go to the [Invoices](https://cloud.ibm.com/billing/invoices) page in the IBM Cloud console.
Here, you can check the status of your invoice.

The possible statuses are:
	* Invoiced: You received the latest invoice from IBM Cloud.
* Paid: Your payment for the charges on your latest invoice was received.
* Unpaid: The charges on your latest invoice have not been paid.
* Pending: Your payment for your latest charges has not been applied due to a payment processing error.
You can also view and download your invoice from the IBM console by clicking the Download icon next to each invoice.
For some accounts, invoices are available through the [Invoices@IBM](http://ibm.com/invoices) website.
If your invoices are managed through the IBM Invoices website, the invoice is paid when the status is Settled.
Why do you think I can not apply a subscription code?

Based on the information provided in the document, you might not be able to apply a subscription code because your account is a child account on an enterprise and subscription codes must be applied at the enterprise level.
You can contact the owner or the administrator of the enterprise to have the subscription code added.

rewritten_query: Why can't I apply a feature code?
agent_response:
Based on the information provided in the document, you might not be able to apply a feature code because of the following reasons:

1. Your account doesn't meet the requirements for the feature code.
2. You don't have the required access in the account.
3. The code expired.

To successfully apply a feature code, you need to have the correct account type, which varies depending on the particular code. You must also have the Editor role or higher for all account management services. To view or change roles, see [Assigning access to account management services](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/account?topic=account-account-services). If you are unable to apply a feature code, you can contact the person who provided the code for help or contact the educational provider for further assistance if it is an educational feature code.

rewritten_query: I have encountered errors when trying to update my credit card.
agent_response:
I'm sorry to hear that you're having trouble updating your credit card. The error might be caused by various issues, such as incorrect card information, a network problem, or a decline from your credit card issuer. Here are some steps you can take to troubleshoot the issue:

1. Verify that the card information you entered is correct, including the card number, expiration date, and CVV code.
2. Check your network connection and consider using a private or incognito window, trying without a VPN or with a different VPN, or using a browser on a different computer or device.
3. If your credit card requires a MasterCard SecureCode sent to a mobile phone, ensure you submit the code correctly, and refresh the manage my wallet page to verify that your new credit card information is saved.
4. If the problem persists, contact your credit card issuer for more information about any potential issues or restrictions, or consider using a different credit card.
5. If you need further assistance, you can contact IBM Cloud Support for help with payment-related issues.

Remember to be assigned the operator role or higher on the billing account management service before managing payments.

rewritten_query: I am getting an error message 'Could not place order. Problem authorizing the credit card. We are unable to process your request: Transaction Rejected' while trying to manage my payments.
agent_response:
This error message indicates that there is an issue with authorizing your credit card for the transaction. This might be due to various reasons, such as incorrect card information, a network problem, or a decline from your credit card issuer. To troubleshoot the issue, you can:

1. Verify that the card information you entered is correct, including the card number, expiration date, and CVV code.
2. Check your network connection and consider using a private or incognito window, trying without a VPN or with a different VPN, or using a browser on a different computer or device.
3. If your credit card requires a MasterCard SecureCode sent to a mobile phone, ensure you submit the code correctly, and refresh the manage my wallet page to verify that your new credit card information is saved.
4. If the problem persists, contact your credit card issuer for more information about any potential issues or restrictions, or consider using a different credit card.
5. If you need further assistance, you can contact IBM Cloud Support for help with payment-related issues. Remember to be assigned the operator role or higher on the billing account management service before managing payments.

rewritten_query: Could you tell me what a strong password is?
agent_response:
A strong password is one that is difficult or improbable for someone to guess, either manually or through automated means. It can have certain characteristics such as being at least 8 characters long, containing one number, one lowercase letter, and one capital letter, having only English letters and numbers, or having at least one unique character. These requirements can be set in the Cloud Directory settings page in the App ID dashboard, or by using the management APIs.

Additionally, a strong password should not include the user's username or the first part of their email address for added security.

It is also important to note that a strong password should not be a dictionary word or a common phrase, and it should not be reused from previous passwords.

It's also good practice to change passwords regularly and to avoid writing them down or sharing them with others.

You can also enforce password constraints such as lockout after repeated wrong credentials, avoiding password reuse, password expiration, minimum period between password changes, and ensuring that the password does not include user name to enhance the security of your application.

rewritten_query: What is the retention time for conversations?
agent_response: The retention time for conversations in Watson Assistant depends on your service plan. For the Enterprise with Data Isolation and Premium (legacy) plans, conversations are retained for the last 90 days, while for the Enterprise and Plus plans, conversations are retained for the last 30 days. After this period, the conversations are automatically removed and cannot be retrieved. You can refer to the Watson Assistant documentation for specific details on your plan's retention policy.

rewritten_query: Can you delete conversations?
agent_response:
Yes, you can delete conversations manually in Watson Assistant. To delete a specific conversation, you can use the Watson Assistant API to delete the message data associated with the conversation. However, you need to have previously associated a unique Customer ID with each message to be able to delete it. If you haven't done this, you won't be able to delete specific messages, but you can still delete the entire conversation history for your Watson Assistant instance. Keep in mind that deleting messages might affect the Overview metrics, such as the Total Conversations count.

To delete the entire conversation history, you can use the IBM Cloud Functions or the Watson Assistant API to delete the messages. However, this will permanently remove all messages, and you won't be able to retrieve them afterward. Make sure to review the documentation and consider the implications before proceeding with deletion.

If you want to delete conversations automatically after a certain period, you can set up conversation retention policies based on your service plan. The Watson Assistant documentation provides specific details on retention policies for different plans.

In summary, you can delete conversations manually or set up automatic retention policies based on your service plan. Remember that deleting messages might affect Overview metrics, and deleting the entire conversation history will permanently remove all messages.

original_query: What are the different types of dialog nodes?
rewritten_query: What are the different types of dialog nodes?
agent_response:
Based on the documents provided, there are two main types of dialog nodes:

1. A node that conditions on an intent value: This type of node is useful to capture questions about a certain topic and then, in the root response, ask a follow-up question that is addressed by the child nodes. It can recognize a user question about a specific topic and ask a follow-up question based on that.

2. A node with slots: This type of node also conditions on an intent value. It defines a set of slots, each for a piece of information that you want to collect from the user. Each slot asks a question to elicit the answer from the user and looks for a specific entity value in the user's reply to the prompt, which it then saves in a slot context variable. This is useful for collecting details you might need to perform a transaction on the user's behalf.

Additionally, there are several response types that can be added to a dialog node, including Connect to human agent, Image, Option, and Pause.

rewritten_query: How is a node with slots created?
agent_response: Intents are created by identifying and labeling examples of user inputs that express the same goal or purpose. This process is often referred to as "training" or "defining" an intent. In the context of a travel booking application, for example, you would start by gathering a variety of user inputs that express the goal of booking a flight, such as "I want to book a flight," "Book a flight for me," "I need a flight reservation," etc. These examples are then provided to the system, which uses machine learning algorithms to identify the common patterns and characteristics among them. Based on this analysis, the system can then recognize and respond to new user inputs that express the same goal, even if they are phrased differently. The process of defining intents is an important step in building a conversational AI system, as it helps the system to understand the user's intention and respond appropriately.

How is it created?
Intents are created by identifying and labeling examples of user inputs that express the same goal or purpose.
This process is often referred to as "training" or "defining" an intent.

In the context of a travel booking application, for example, you would start by gathering a variety of user inputs that express the goal of booking a flight, such as "I want to book a flight," "Book a flight for me," "I need a flight reservation," etc.
These examples are then provided to the system, which uses machine learning algorithms to identify the common patterns and characteristics among them.
Based on this analysis, the system can then recognize and respond to new user inputs that express the same goal, even if they are phrased differently.
The process of defining intents is an important step in building a conversational AI system, as it helps the system to understand the user's intention and respond appropriately.

rewritten_query: Could you clarify the difference between a dialog node and what?
agent_response:
Intents and dialog nodes are related but serve different purposes in a conversational AI system. Intents are a way to categorize what a user wants to do, representing a goal or purpose of a user's input. They are created by identifying and labeling examples of user inputs that express the same goal or purpose. Dialog nodes, on the other hand, are the building blocks of a conversation flow in the system. They represent the start of a thread of dialog between the assistant and the user and contain conditions that must be met for the node to be processed. Dialog nodes can contain slots to gather information from the user, and they can have different response types, such as Connect to human agent, Image, Option, and Pause.

In summary, intents help the system understand the user's intention, while dialog nodes define the flow of the conversation based on the user's intent and gather any necessary information to respond or perform a transaction on the user's behalf.

rewritten_query: What are the advantages of adding a skill to my assistant?
agent_response: Yes, there are several advantages to adding a skill to your assistant. Skills allow you to customize your assistant by adding the specific capabilities it needs to satisfy your customers' goals. Conversational skills understand and address questions or requests that your customers typically ask about, while a search skill searches for and returns passages from existing self-service content. By adding skills to your assistant, you can provide more comprehensive and accurate responses to a wider range of user queries. Additionally, skills can help streamline the conversation flow and improve the overall user experience. The specific benefits will depend on the type of skill you add and how you configure it to meet your needs.

A node with slots: This type of node also conditions on an intent value.

Whatar are intents?
Intents are a way to categorize what a user wants to do.
They represent a goal or purpose of a user's input.
For example, in a travel booking application, "book a flight" or "check flight status" could be two different intents.
Defining intents helps the system to understand the user's intention and respond appropriately.
How is it created?
Intents are created by identifying and labeling examples of user inputs that express the same goal or purpose.
This process is often referred to as "training" or "defining" an intent.

In the context of a travel booking application, for example, you would start by gathering a variety of user inputs that express the goal of booking a flight, such as "I want to book a flight," "Book a flight for me," "I need a flight reservation," etc.
These examples are then provided to the system, which uses machine learning algorithms to identify the common patterns and characteristics among them.
Based on this analysis, the system can then recognize and respond to new user inputs that express the same goal, even if they are phrased differently.
The process of defining intents is an important step in building a conversational AI system, as it helps the system to understand the user's intention and respond appropriately.
Are those the only steps?
Based on the document provided, those are the main steps in creating intents.
First, you gather examples of user inputs that express the same goal or purpose.
Then, you provide these examples to the system, which uses machine learning algorithms to identify common patterns and characteristics.
Finally, the system can recognize and respond to new user inputs that express the same goal, even if they are phrased differently.
However, it's important to note that the process of defining intents may involve iterative refinement and improvement as the system learns and adapts to user inputs.
Are dialogue skills necessary?
Dialog skills are not explicitly mentioned as a requirement for creating intents.

They can gather any information needed to respond or perform a transaction on the user's behalf.
So, while not a strict requirement for creating intents, dialog skills are an essential component of a fully functional conversational AI system.

rewritten_query: I want to create a search skill.
agent_response: A search skill is a type of skill that allows your assistant to search for and return passages from existing self-service content. This can be useful when a customer asks a question that the dialog is not designed to answer. The search skill can search for relevant information from Discovery, extract the information, and return it as the response. This feature is available only to Watson Assistant Plus or Premium plan users. By adding a search skill to your assistant, you can improve the comprehensiveness and accuracy of the assistant's responses to user queries, particularly for complex inquiries that require access to external data sources.

original_query: How can I update the cluster master?
rewritten_query: How can I update the cluster master?
agent_response: To update the cluster master, you can use the `ibmcloud ks cluster master update` command. If you don't want to update the master to the default major.minor version during the update, include the `--version` option and specify the latest patch version that is available for the major.minor version that you want, such as 1.26. You can list available versions by running `ibmcloud ks versions`. Please note that you cannot roll back a cluster to a previous version after the update process takes place. It's recommended to use a test cluster and follow the instructions to address potential issues before you update your production master.

rewritten_query: Which command should I use to update the cluster master according to the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark?
agent_response:
The CIS (Center for Internet Security) Kubernetes Benchmark is a set of specific steps to configure Kubernetes more securely, in line with various industry regulations. The benchmark is versioned, and the documents you provided contain the results of the version 1.5 CIS Kubernetes benchmark for clusters running Kubernetes versions 1.21, 1.25, 1.26, and 1.27. The benchmark checks various aspects of Kubernetes configuration, including master node security configurations, which involve checking the permissions and ownership of configuration files for the API server, controller manager, scheduler, and etcd pods, as well as the Container Network Interface.

If you need more information about using the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark, you can refer to the Using the benchmark section in the IBM Cloud documentation.

If you have any specific questions or concerns related to the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark, please let me know and I'll do my best to assist you.

rewritten_query: What are some recommended practices for IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service?
agent_response:
Here are some recommended practices for IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service:

1. Set up a Continuous Integration (CI) toolchain to run a static code scanner on the application repositories, build container images on every Git commit, test the Dockerfile before the image is created, and store the built image in a private image registry.
2. Implement security vulnerability scanning for container images.
3. Use API tokens for target cluster deployment access permissions, which can be revoked.
4. Implement a Docker signature upon successful completion and insert the built image tag into the deployment manifest automatically.
5. Implement continuous deployment with inventory integration, change management with Git Repos and Issue Tracking, evidence collection, and deployment to IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service.
6. Ensure that your deployed artifacts and their source repositories are always compliant using the toolchain template for continuous compliance (CC).
7. Use the CIS (Center for Internet Security) Kubernetes Benchmark, a versioned set of specific steps to configure Kubernetes more securely, to check various aspects of Kubernetes configuration, including master node security configurations.

For more information on these practices, you can refer to the provided documents.

rewritten_query: Could you explain what Kubernetes means?
agent_response: Kubernetes is an open-source platform for managing containerized workloads and services across multiple hosts. It offers management tools for deploying, automating, monitoring, and scaling containerized applications with minimal manual intervention. The containers that make up your microservice are grouped into pods, a logical unit to ensure easy management and discovery. These pods run on compute hosts that are managed in a Kubernetes cluster that is portable, extensible, and self-healing in case of failures. For more information, you can check out the Kubernetes documentation.

rewritten_query: Could you explain how IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service works and why I should use it?
agent_response:
IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service is a managed Kubernetes offering on IBM Cloud that provides powerful tools, an intuitive user experience, and built-in security for rapid delivery of applications that you can bind to various cloud services such as IBM Watson, AI, IoT, DevOps, security, and data analytics. The service is a certified Kubernetes provider that offers features like intelligent scheduling, self-healing, horizontal scaling, service discovery and load balancing, automated rollouts and rollbacks, and secret and configuration management.

Advanced capabilities of the service include simplified cluster management, container security and isolation policies, the ability to design your own cluster, and integrated operational tools for consistency in deployment. The service supports two container management platforms: the IBM version of community Kubernetes and Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud, which can be installed on your cluster master and worker nodes.

IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service is ideal for high availability, high-performance compute, easy spin-up of clusters for faster development, and AI from IBM Watson. For example, a mortgage company was able to reduce costs, increase worldwide availability, accelerate regulatory compliance, and improve risk analysis by using the service. Similarly, a healthcare provider improved patient service by migrating workloads from inefficient VMs to Ops-friendly containers for reporting and patient systems.

In summary, IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service offers a managed Kubernetes platform with advanced capabilities, easy spin-up of clusters, and support for various workloads such as analytics, inventory management, and market insights. It can help you reduce costs, improve availability, accelerate development, and enhance security.

extracted_sentences: How can I update the cluster master?
To update the cluster master, you can use the `ibmcloud ks cluster master update` command.

If you don't want to update the master to the default major.minor version during the update, include the `--version` option and specify the latest patch version that is available for the major.minor version that you want, such as 1.26.
You can list available versions by running `ibmcloud ks versions`.
Please note that you cannot roll back a cluster to a previous version after the update process takes place.
It's recommended to use a test cluster and follow the instructions to address potential issues before you update your production master.
CIS Kubernetes Benchmark
The CIS (Center for Internet Security) Kubernetes Benchmark is a set of specific steps to configure Kubernetes more securely, in line with various industry regulations.
The benchmark is versioned, and the documents you provided contain the results of the version 1.5 CIS Kubernetes benchmark for clusters running Kubernetes versions 1.21, 1.25, 1.26, and 1.27.

The benchmark checks various aspects of Kubernetes configuration, including master node security configurations, which involve checking the permissions and ownership of configuration files for the API server, controller manager, scheduler, and etcd pods, as well as the Container Network Interface.
If you need more information about using the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark, you can refer to the Using the benchmark section in the IBM Cloud documentation.
If you have any specific questions or concerns related to the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark, please let me know and I'll do my best to assist you.

rewritten_query: What are the options and access I should grant to secure my cluster?
agent_response:
To secure your IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service cluster, you can use built-in security features provided by the service. These features include securing the Kubernetes API server, etcd data store, worker node, network, storage, images, and deployments against malicious attacks. You can also leverage built-in logging and monitoring tools to detect malicious attacks and suspicious usage patterns.

When it comes to access policies, IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service uses Cloud Identity and Access Management (IAM) to grant access to cluster resources. There are two types of access policies: IAM platform access roles and IAM service access roles. The access policies that you assign users vary depending on what you want your users to be able to do. You can find more information about what roles authorize which types of actions on the User access reference page or in the following table's links.

If you want to restrict access to your cluster, you can create custom roles and bind them to users or teams. You can also use Kubernetes role-based access control (RBAC) policies to control access to Kubernetes resources within your cluster.

For more information about how to secure your cluster and assign access policies, you can refer to the IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service documentation on Security and Access Control.

If you have data that must be available, even if an outage occurs, make sure to store your data on persistent storage. Additionally, for high availability, you can refer to the IBM Cloud documentation on High availability for Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud.

Regarding the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark, it is a set of specific steps to configure Kubernetes more securely. You can follow the guidelines in the IBM Cloud documentation to implement the benchmark in your cluster.

If you have any specific questions or concerns related to the security of your IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service cluster, please let me know and I'll do my best to assist you.

rewritten_query: Can I get some information about service support in case I run into some issues?
agent_response:
Yes, IBM provides support for its Cloud Kubernetes Service through various channels. You can open a support case by using the IBM Cloud Support Center. To do this, you must have a Pay-As-You-Go or Subscription account and be assigned at least the editor role on the Support Center account management service. For more information, you can refer to the documents on "Assigning access to account management services" and "Assigning user access for working with support cases". 

When opening a support case, you should provide as much information as possible, such as the operating system, client version, associated logs, and details about the destination being used. 

For more details on support case severity and initial response times, you can refer to the document on "Case severity and initial response times". You can also change your current support plan at any time by contacting an IBM Cloud Sales representative. 

Additionally, if you encounter issues with Partner Center, you can create a support case by using the IBM Cloud Support Center. The process is similar to creating a case for other services, but you should select Partner Center - Sell as the topic. 

For more information about opening an IBM support ticket, or about support levels and ticket severities, you can refer to the document on "Contacting support".

rewritten_query: does IBM offer document databases?
agent_response: Yes, IBM offers a document database service called IBM Cloudant. It is a JSON document store that includes collections called databases, each of which contain any number of documents. An IBM Cloudant document must be a JSON object, starting and ending with curly braces and containing a number of key-value attributes. For more information, you can refer to the Introduction to IBM Cloudant course, specifically part 2 - The IBM Cloudant Document.

rewritten_query: Can it store any random JSON object, or do I need to specify fields in advance?
agent_response: In IBM Cloudant, a document must be a JSON object, which means it should start and end with curly braces and contain key-value attributes. You can store any valid JSON object in it, without needing to specify the fields in advance. The system will automatically detect the fields and their data types during the ingestion process. However, if you plan to use custom tokenization for Japanese collections with the Discovery API, you should add the tokenization dictionary for your collection before uploading documents.

rewritten_query: Can I store an image or PDF within a document in IBM Cloudant?
agent_response: IBM Cloudant allows you to store attachments with a document, which can be used for storing images or PDFs. Attachments are Binary Large OBject (BLOB) files included within documents. To create a new attachment at the same time as creating a new document, you can include the attachment as an inline component of the JSON content. For an existing document, you can make a PUT request with the document's most recent revision to a specific URL to create or update an attachment. However, it's important to keep in mind that larger binary data attachments can impact performance and increase costs, so it's recommended to store only attachment metadata in IBM Cloudant documents and use a separate block store for larger binary files. For more information on attachments, you can refer to the IBM Cloudant documentation on how to use attachments.

rewritten_query: What is the file size limit for attachments in IBM Cloudant?
agent_response:
Yes, there is a limit on the file size for individual documents, single attachments, and request bodies in IBM Cloudant. Individual documents cannot exceed 1 MB, single attachments are limited to 10 MB, and the request body size cannot be more than 11 MB. If these limits are exceeded, a 413 response will be returned. The IBM Cloudant team recommends storing binary attachments or large JSON blobs in object storage and saving a link to the location in an IBM Cloudant JSON document. When replicating, documents or attachments that exceed these limits do not replicate to the target database. For more information about how to detect replication errors, see [Replication errors](https://cloud.ibm.com/apidocs/cloudantgetreplicationdocument).

Regarding the database size limit, it is recommended to consult the IBM Cloudant team if your database is likely to exceed 5 TB in size, as shown in Table 1 of the Databases section.

It is also worth mentioning that the document size should be kept small (ideally in single-digit KB) for optimal performance, since JSON decoding becomes costly as documents grow. Avoid using attachments for larger binary files, such as images and videos, as they can impact performance and increase costs. Instead, store only attachment metadata in IBM Cloudant documents and use a separate block store for larger binary files.

rewritten_query: What is the difference between the lite and standard plans in IBM Cloudant?
agent_response:
The Lite plan for IBM Cloudant is a free plan designed for development and evaluation purposes. It includes all of IBM Cloudant's functions, but the provisioned throughput capacity and data storage are fixed at 20 reads per second, 10 writes per second, 5 global queries per second, and 1 GB, respectively. This means that if you exceed the 1 GB data storage limit, you will not be able to write new data unless you upgrade to a paid plan or delete data to reduce your storage usage. Additionally, you can only have one IBM Cloudant Lite plan instance per IBM Cloud account.

On the other hand, the Standard plan for IBM Cloudant is a paid plan that offers configurable provisioned throughput capacity and data storage pricing that scales as your application requirements change. This means that you can store more than 1 GB of data and adjust the provisioned throughput capacity to meet the needs of your application.

Overall, the main difference between the Lite and Standard plans is that the Lite plan has fixed and limited resources, while the Standard plan offers more flexibility and scalability for a fee.

rewritten_query: Where can I find the Python SDK for pushing and fetching data?
agent_response:
You can find the IBM Cloudant Python SDK in the IBM Cloud documentation, which provides examples for pushing and fetching data. Additionally, IBM provides an IBM Cloudant library for Python called `ibm-cloudant` that can be installed via pip. The library's documentation provides comprehensive examples and instructions for using it to interact with IBM Cloudant.

To install the library, type the following command into a command line:

`pip install ibm-cloudant`

Here is an example of how to use the library to push data to IBM Cloudant:

```python
from ibm_cloudant.cloudant_v1 import CloudantV1
from ibm_cloud_sdk_core.authenticators import IAMAuthenticator

authenticator = IAMAuthenticator('your-iam-api-key')
service = CloudantV1(authenticator=authenticator)

service.set_service_url('your-cloudant-service-url')

database_name = 'your-database-name'

# Create a new database
service.post_database(database_name=database_name).get_result()

# Push data to the database
doc_id = 'your-document-id'
document = {
    '_id': doc_id,
    'your-field-name': 'your-field-value'
}

service.post_document(database_name=database_name, document=document).get_result()
```

And here is an example of how to use the library to fetch data from IBM Cloudant:

```python
from ibm_cloudant.cloudant_v1 import CloudantV1
from ibm_cloud_sdk_core.authenticators import IAMAuthenticator

authenticator = IAMAuthenticator('your-iam-api-key')
service = CloudantV1(authenticator=authenticator)

service.set_service_url('your-cloudant-service-url')

database_name = 'your-database-name'

# Fetch all documents in the database
all_docs = service.get_all_docs(database_name=database_name).get_result()

# Print the

agent_response:
Yes, if you want to build a skill that supports Hebrew, which is a language with right-to-left directional text, you can configure the bidirectional capabilities. The universal language model will adapt to understand and support Hebrew as you add training data in that language.

For more information, see [Configuring bidirectional languages](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/assistant?topic=assistant-language-supportlanguage-support-configure-bidirectional).

To set the bidirectional capabilities for a language like Hebrew, follow these steps:

1. Click the options icon from the skill tile in your Watson Assistant.

3. Click the Enable bidirectional capabilities switch.

original_query: How can I delete a key?
rewritten_query: How can I delete a key?
agent_response:
To delete a key in Unified Key Orchestrator using the IBM Cloud console, you need to follow these steps:

1. Log in to the Hyper Protect Crypto Services instance.
2. Click on "Managed keys" from the navigation to view all the available keys.
3. If the managed key you want to delete is in Active state, click the Actions icon and choose "Deactivated" to deactivate the key first. This step is not necessary if the key is in Pre-active or Deactivated state.
4. After deactivating the key (if it was in Active state), click the Actions icon again and choose "Destroyed" to destroy the key.
5. Finally, click the Actions icon and choose "Remove from vault" to remove the key and its metadata from the vault.

Please note that when you destroy a managed key, the key cannot be restored in Unified Key Orchestrator. However, you can still restore your keys in external keystores depending on the settings of the cloud providers.

Also, keep in mind that you cannot delete a key ring as long as it contains keys in any state. If you want to delete a key ring, you might need to transfer keys to a different ring first.

rewritten_query: What happens when the first user authorizes a key for deletion?
agent_response: When the first user authorizes a key for deletion in Hyper Protect Crypto Services, it remains in the Active state for seven days. During this time, all key operations are allowed on the key. The second user with a Manager access policy can use the IBM Cloud console or API to delete the key at any point during these seven days, moving the key to the Destroyed state. It is important to note that because it is impossible to purge an active key, another user must delete the key before it can be purged. After deletion, the key and its associated data will be inaccessible 90 days after being deleted and will be eligible to be automatically purged after 90 days, resulting in the permanent removal of the key and its associated data from the Key Protect service.

rewritten_query: Can I remove the entry from the resource list if the server expired?
agent_response: Yes, if a server has expired, you can remove the entry from the resource list. This can be done by manually triggering the deletion from the resource reclamations. If you wait for the target time, the server will be automatically deleted after the seven-day reclamation period ends. During this period, you can still restore the virtual server. However, if the server has expired and been deleted at the backend, restoring it will only restore the entry within the resource list, not the server itself.

original_query: Why could not I delete keys?
extracted_sentences: How can I delete a key?

To delete a key in Unified Key Orchestrator using the IBM Cloud console, you need to follow these steps:

1.
Log in to the Hyper Protect Crypto Services instance.
Click on "Managed keys" from the navigation to view all the available keys.
If the managed key you want to delete is in Active state, click the Actions icon and choose "Deactivated" to deactivate the key first.
This step is not necessary if the key is in Pre-active or Deactivated state.
After deactivating the key (if it was in Active state), click the Actions icon again and choose "Destroyed" to destroy the key.
Finally, click the Actions icon and choose "Remove from vault" to remove the key and its metadata from the vault.
Please note that when you destroy a managed key, the key cannot be restored in Unified Key Orchestrator.
However, you can still restore your keys in external keystores depending on the settings of the cloud providers.
Also, keep in mind that you cannot delete a key ring as long as it contains keys in any state.
If you want to delete a key ring, you might need to transfer keys to a different ring first.
what happen when the first user authorizes a key for deletion?
When the first user authorizes a key for deletion in Hyper Protect Crypto Services, it remains in the Active state for seven days.
During this time, all key operations are allowed on the key.
The second user with a Manager access policy can use the IBM Cloud console or API to delete the key at any point during these seven days, moving the key to the Destroyed state.
It is important to note that because it is impossible to purge an active key, another user must delete the key before it can be purged.

After deletion, the key and its associated data will be inaccessible 90 days after being deleted and will be eligible to be automatically purged after 90 days, resulting in the permanent removal of the key and its associated data from the Key Protect service.

rewritten_query: Why can't I delete keys?
agent_response: There could be several reasons why you cannot delete keys. One possible reason is that the key you want to delete is in Active state and you have not deactivated it first. Another reason could be that you do not have the necessary permissions to delete keys. You must have the service "Manager" role of both the key being transferred and the target key ring to transfer a key. If you are trying to delete a key ring, you cannot do so if it contains keys in any state. You might need to transfer keys to a different ring first. If none of these reasons apply, you may need to contact IBM support for further assistance.

rewritten_query: What could happen if I force a deletion on a key?
agent_response: If you force a deletion on a key in IBM Key Protect, it will be deleted immediately, along with any data encrypted by the key. However, if the key is protecting a registered IBM Cloud resource that's non-erasable due to a retention policy, the force deletion will not succeed. You can verify whether a key is associated with a non-erasable resource by checking the 'preventKeyDeletion' field in the registration details for the key. If it is, you must contact an account owner to remove the retention policy on each registered IBM Cloud resource that is associated with the key before you can delete the key.

rewritten_query: What happens when the second user uses Cryptoshredding to delete a key within these seven days?
agent_response: Cryptoshredding is a destructive action that makes your data unrecoverable when the key is deleted. Hyper Protect Crypto Services and Key Protect allow initiating a force delete of a key in use by IBM Cloud services, including your Cloud Databases deployments, which is called cryptoshredding. Deleting a key that is in use on your deployment locks the disks that contain your data and disables your deployment. You are still able to access the UI and some metadata such as security settings in the UI, CLI, and API but you are not able to access any of the databases or data that is contained within them. Key deletion is sent to the Activity Tracker as hs-crypto.secrets.delete or secrets.delete.

rewritten_query: What happens to the backups when the first user authorizes a key for deletion?
agent_response: If you want to delete the backups of your Cloud Databases deployment, you can delete the key used for encryption. Once the key is deleted, Cloud Object Storage will ensure that the storage is unreadable and unwriteable. However, any other deployments that use the same key for backups will encounter subsequent backup failures. Therefore, it is important to use different keys for the backups of multiple deployments. If you delete just the Cloud Object Storage authorization, any deployments that use the same key will encounter temporary backup failures until the policy is automatically re-created. However, if you delete both the Cloud Object Storage authorization and the Cloud Databases delegator authorization, all deployments that use the same key will immediately lose the ability to back up and the correct authorizations will not be able to be re-created, effectively destroying the backups for all deployments that use that key.

If you wait for the target time, the server will be automatically deleted after the seven-day reclamation period ends.
During this period, you can still restore the virtual server.
However, if the server has expired and been deleted at the backend, restoring it will only restore the entry within the resource list, not the server itself.
Why could not I delete keys?
There could be several reasons why you cannot delete keys.
One possible reason is that the key you want to delete is in Active state and you have not deactivated it first.
Another reason could be that you do not have the necessary permissions to delete keys.
You must have the service "Manager" role of both the key being transferred and the target key ring to transfer a key.
If you are trying to delete a key ring, you cannot do so if it contains keys in any state.
You might need to transfer keys to a different ring first.
If none of these reasons apply, you may need to contact IBM support for further assistance.
What could happen if I force a deletion on a key?
If you force a deletion on a key in IBM Key Protect, it will be deleted immediately, along with any data encrypted by the key.
However, if the key is protecting a registered IBM Cloud resource that's non-erasable due to a retention policy, the force deletion will not succeed.
You can verify whether a key is associated with a non-erasable resource by checking the 'preventKeyDeletion' field in the registration details for the key.
If it is, you must contact an account owner to remove the retention policy on each registered IBM Cloud resource that is associated with the key before you can delete the key.
Cryptoshredding is a destructive action that makes your data unrecoverable when the key is deleted.
Hyper Protect Crypto Services and Key Protect allow initiating a force delete of a key in use by IBM Cloud services, including your Cloud Databases deployments, which is called cryptoshredding.
Deleting a key that is in use on your deployment locks the disks that contain your data and disables your deployment.
You are still able to access the UI and some metadata such as security settings in the UI, CLI, and API but you are not able to access any of the databases or data that is contained within them.
Key deletion is sent to the Activity Tracker as hs-crypto.secrets.delete or secrets.delete.
If you want to delete the backups of your Cloud Databases deployment, you can delete the key used for encryption.
Once the key is deleted, Cloud Object Storage will ensure that the storage is unreadable and unwriteable.
However, any other deployments that use the same key for backups will encounter subsequent backup failures.
Therefore, it is important to use different keys for the backups of multiple deployments.
If you delete just the Cloud Object Storage authorization, any deployments that use the same key will encounter temporary backup failures until the policy is automatically re-created.

However, if you delete both the Cloud Object Storage authorization and the Cloud Databases delegator authorization, all deployments that use the same key will immediately lose the ability to back up and the correct authorizations will not be able to be re-created, effectively destroying the backups for all deployments that use that key.

rewritten_query: What is the plan for Disaster Recovery?
agent_response:
IBM Cloud has business continuity plans in place to provide for the recovery of services within hours if a disaster occurs. Projects don't replicate data outside of a region, except for backup data. When possible, backup data is kept within the data centers of a country but data is always kept within a geography. European data does not leave the EU. IBM Cloud performs regular electronic backups of project data with Recovery Time Objective (RTO) and Recovery Point Objective (RPO) of hours as documented in the IBM Cloud Disaster Recovery Plan. You are responsible for your data backup and associated recovery of your content. For more information about your responsibilities when using projects, see Shared responsibilities for projects.

If you have specific questions related to disaster recovery for your project, you can contact IBM support for further assistance.

original_query: What are the steps involved to delete the CIS instance?
rewritten_query: What are the steps involved to delete the CIS instance?
agent_response:
Based on the information provided in the documents, here are the steps to delete a CIS instance:

1. Delete all global load balancers, pools, and health checks.
2. Delete the associated domain (zone). Go to the Overview page and click the trash can icon next to the domain name located in the Service Details section to start the deletion process.
3. If you are moving your domain to a different provider, be sure to migrate your DNS records and other configuration information to the new provider before activating the domain there. Activating the domain before migrating from CIS can cause your domain to changed to a Moved state.
4. You cannot delete the CIS instance after you add a domain. To delete the instance, delete the domain from the instance first.

Please note that these steps assume that you have the necessary permissions to delete the CIS instance and its associated resources.

rewritten_query: Is it possible to add a custom domain?
agent_response:
Based on the provided document, you can add a custom domain in IBM Cloud Foundry by following these steps:

1. Go to Manage > Account, and select Cloud Foundry orgs.
2. Click the name of the org for which you're creating a custom domain.
3. Click the Domains tab to view a list of available domains.
4. Click Add a domain, enter your domain name, and select the region.
5. Confirm your updates, and click Add.

Please note that the IBM Cloud Foundry service is deprecated and will no longer be supported as of 1 June 2023.

rewritten_query: Can you explain what the transportation layer is?
agent_response: The transportation layer is a part of a computer network's protocol stack that is responsible for the delivery of data between applications running on networked hosts. It is the fourth layer in the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model and the third layer in the TCP/IP model. It provides services such as connection-oriented communication, reliability, flow control, and multiplexing. The two main protocols used at this layer are the Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and the User Datagram Protocol (UDP).

What is the transportation layer?
The transportation layer is a part of a computer network's protocol stack that is responsible for the delivery of data between applications running on networked hosts.
It is the fourth layer in the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model and the third layer in the TCP/IP model.
It provides services such as connection-oriented communication, reliability, flow control, and multiplexing.
The two main protocols used at this layer are the Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and the User Datagram Protocol (UDP).

rewritten_query: I'm allowed to use only my firewall rules.
agent_response:
If you are allowed to use only your firewall rules, you should follow these steps:

1. Determine the type of firewall rule you need to create (access-rules, ua-rules, or lockdowns).
2. Identify the DNS domain ID associated with the domain you want to apply the rule to. This is required for ua-rules and lockdowns type rules.
3. Use the `ibmcloud cis firewall-update` command with the appropriate parameters to create your firewall rule.

For example, to create a lockdown rule for a specific domain, you can use the following command:

```
ibmcloud cis firewall-update e6106d7ec58e47ebb2fa053dedcd7dcb -t lockdowns -d 31984fea73a15b45779fa0df4ef62f9b --json '{"urls": ["api.mysite.com/some/endpoint"], "configurations": [{"target": "ip", "value": "127.0.0.1"}, {"target": "ip_range", "value": "2.2.2.0/24"}]}' -i "cis-demo"
```

This command will lock down access to the specified URLs to only the IP address and IP range you specified.

4. Test your firewall rule to ensure that it is working as intended.

Remember that firewall rules can be based on IP address, IP address range, Autonomous System Number (ASN), or country/region. Also, keep in mind that domain lockdown rules specify a list of IP addresses, CIDR ranges, or networks that can access a domain, subdomain, or URL, and anything not on the list is blocked.

A negative score indicates that there is less agreement than would be expected by chance.

After the reclaim period expires, the data is destroyed and the volume is removed from the console.

original_query: What are the steps to be taken to gather the relevant worker node data?
rewritten_query: What are the steps to be taken to gather the relevant worker node data?
agent_response:
To gather the relevant worker node data, follow these steps:

1. Check the conditions of your worker nodes and cluster before you gather data.
2. Check the CPU and memory level of your nodes. If any node is over 80% in either CPU or memory usage, consider provisioning more nodes or reducing your workload.
3. Gather information about your worker nodes by using the command `kubectl top node` (for IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service) or `oc top node` (for IBM Cloud Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud).
4. Open a support ticket and include the worker node information you gathered.

Before opening a support ticket, it's recommended to review the information and follow any troubleshooting steps in the documents related to debugging worker nodes, worker node states, and troubleshooting worker nodes in Critical or NotReady state.

If only some of your worker nodes are affected, you must gather the relevant data to include in your support ticket. However, if all worker nodes in a cluster, or in a single zone, subnet, or VLAN are affected, you can open an initial support ticket without gathering data. You might later be asked to gather the relevant data.

Reference(s):
- IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service: <https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-ts-critical-notreadyts-critical-notready-gather>
- IBM Cloud Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud: <https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/openshift?topic=openshift-ts-critical-notreadyts-critical-notready-gather>

rewritten_query: What are the steps to update a classic worker node?
agent_response:
To update a classic worker node, you can use the `ibmcloud ks worker update` command. This command updates the classic worker node to the latest patch, and if a major.minor version update is also available, it updates the worker node to the same major.minor version as the master and latest patch version.

Here's an example command to update a worker node named `myworker` in the `mycluster` cluster:

```
ibmcloud ks worker update myworker --cluster mycluster
```

Keep in mind that your worker nodes can be only up to two versions behind the master version (n-2).

If you want to update the worker node to a specific patch version, you can use the `--patch-version` option followed by the desired patch version.

For more information, you can refer to the IBM Cloud documentation on [Update types](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-cs_versionsupdate_types).

It's also important to note that if you have apps running on worker nodes that you update, they may be rescheduled onto other worker nodes in the cluster. To avoid downtime for your app, you must ensure that you have enough capacity in the cluster to carry the workload.

If you need to control how many worker nodes go down at a time during an update or reload, you can consider resizing your worker pool or adding stand-alone worker nodes to add more worker nodes. You can remove the additional worker nodes after the update is completed.

If you encounter any issues during the update process, you can open a support ticket and include the relevant worker node information. Before opening a support ticket, it's recommended to review the information and follow any troubleshooting steps in the documents related to debugging worker nodes, worker node states, and troubleshooting worker nodes in Critical or NotReady state.

Reference(s):
- IBM Cloud: <https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-cs_versionsupdate_types>
- IBM Cloud: <https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-ts-critical-notreadyts-critical-notready-gather>
- IBM Cloud Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud: <https://cloud.ibm

rewritten_query: I want to do a major.minor update.
agent_response:
A major.minor update in Kubernetes involves updating the Kubernetes version of the worker node to the same version as the master. This type of update often includes changes to the Kubernetes API or other behaviors that you must prepare your cluster for. Remember that your worker nodes can only be one version behind the master version (n-1). You can update the classic worker node to the same patch by using the `ibmcloud oc worker update` command.

Before performing a major.minor update, it is recommended to back up your app data and complete the following steps for one worker node at a time:

Step 1: Update the cluster master

1. If you are updating your worker nodes to a new major version, such as from 4.11 to 4.12, update the cluster master first.

ibmcloud oc cluster master update --cluster CLUSTER [--version MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH] [--force-update] [-f] [-q]

Example command:

ibmcloud oc cluster master update --cluster mycluster --version 4.11.42 --force-update
2. Wait until the master update finishes.

It is important to note that if you have apps running on worker nodes that you update, they may be rescheduled onto other worker nodes in the cluster. To avoid downtime for your app, you must ensure that you have enough capacity in the cluster to carry the workload.

If you need all your worker nodes to be up and running, consider resizing your worker pool or adding stand-alone worker nodes to add more worker nodes. You can remove the additional worker nodes after the update is completed.

In addition, you can create a Kubernetes config map that specifies the maximum number of worker nodes that can be unavailable at a time, such as during an update. Worker nodes are identified by the worker node labels. You can use IBM-provided labels or custom labels that you added to the worker node.

For more information, see [Update types](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-cs_versionsupdate_types).

If you encounter any issues during the update process, you can open a support ticket and include the relevant worker node information. Before opening a support ticket, it's recommended to review the information and follow any troubleshooting

agent_response: A tag is a key-value pair that can be used to identify and organize resources in IBM Cloud. It consists of two parts: a key and a value. The key is a unique identifier for the tag, and the value is a string that provides additional information about the tagged resource. For example, in the tag "costctr:1234", "costctr" is the key and "1234" is the value. Tags can be used to filter and manage resources, such as clusters, storage devices, or Watson services, across IBM Cloud accounts.

original_query: node data
extracted_sentences: What are the steps to be taken to gather the relevant worker node data?

To gather the relevant worker node data, follow these steps:

1.
Check the conditions of your worker nodes and cluster before you gather data.
Check the CPU and memory level of your nodes.
If any node is over 80% in either CPU or memory usage, consider provisioning more nodes or reducing your workload.
Gather information about your worker nodes by using the command `kubectl top node` (for IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service) or `oc top node` (for IBM Cloud Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud).
Open a support ticket and include the worker node information you gathered.

Before opening a support ticket, it's recommended to review the information and follow any troubleshooting steps in the documents related to debugging worker nodes, worker node states, and troubleshooting worker nodes in Critical or NotReady state.
If only some of your worker nodes are affected, you must gather the relevant data to include in your support ticket.
However, if all worker nodes in a cluster, or in a single zone, subnet, or VLAN are affected, you can open an initial support ticket without gathering data.
You might later be asked to gather the relevant data.

Reference(s):
- IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service: <https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-ts-critical-notreadyts-critical-notready-gather>
- IBM Cloud Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud: <https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/openshift?topic=openshift-ts-critical-notreadyts-critical-notready-gather>
How can i update a classic worker node?
To update a classic worker node, you can use the `ibmcloud ks worker update` command.

This command updates the classic worker node to the latest patch, and if a major.minor version update is also available, it updates the worker node to the same major.minor version as the master and latest patch version.

Here's an example command to update a worker node named `myworker` in the `mycluster` cluster:

```
ibmcloud ks worker update myworker --cluster mycluster
```

Keep in mind that your worker nodes can be only up to two versions behind the master version (n-2).
If you want to update the worker node to a specific patch version, you can use the `--patch-version` option followed by the desired patch version.
For more information, you can refer to the IBM Cloud documentation on [Update types](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-cs_versionsupdate_types).
It's also important to note that if you have apps running on worker nodes that you update, they may be rescheduled onto other worker nodes in the cluster.
To avoid downtime for your app, you must ensure that you have enough capacity in the cluster to carry the workload.
If you need to control how many worker nodes go down at a time during an update or reload, you can consider resizing your worker pool or adding stand-alone worker nodes to add more worker nodes.
You can remove the additional worker nodes after the update is completed.
If you encounter any issues during the update process, you can open a support ticket and include the relevant worker node information.

Major. menor update.
A major.minor update in Kubernetes involves updating the Kubernetes version of the worker node to the same version as the master.
This type of update often includes changes to the Kubernetes API or other behaviors that you must prepare your cluster for.
Remember that your worker nodes can only be one version behind the master version (n-1).
You can update the classic worker node to the same patch by using the `ibmcloud oc worker update` command.

Before performing a major.minor update, it is recommended to back up your app data and complete the following steps for one worker node at a time:

Step 1: Update the cluster master

1.
If you are updating your worker nodes to a new major version, such as from 4.11 to 4.12, update the cluster master first.

ibmcloud oc cluster master update --cluster CLUSTER [--version MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH] [--force-update] [-f] [-q]

Example command:

ibmcloud oc cluster master update --cluster mycluster --version 4.11.42 --force-update
2.
Wait until the master update finishes.
It is important to note that if you have apps running on worker nodes that you update, they may be rescheduled onto other worker nodes in the cluster.
If you need all your worker nodes to be up and running, consider resizing your worker pool or adding stand-alone worker nodes to add more worker nodes.
In addition, you can create a Kubernetes config map that specifies the maximum number of worker nodes that can be unavailable at a time, such as during an update.
Worker nodes are identified by the worker node labels.
You can use IBM-provided labels or custom labels that you added to the worker node.
For more information, see [Update types](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-cs_versionsupdate_types).

rewritten_query: Could you please provide more information about the 'node data'? Are you referring to the worker node information that should be included in the support ticket?
agent_response:
To gather the relevant worker node data, follow these steps:

1. Check the conditions of your worker nodes and cluster before you gather data.
2. Check the CPU and memory level of your nodes. If any node is over 80% in either CPU or memory usage, consider provisioning more nodes or reducing your workload.
3. Gather information about your worker nodes by using the command `kubectl top node` (for IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service) or `oc top node` (for IBM Cloud Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud).
4. Save the output details to include in your support ticket. You can get the details of each node using the command `kubectl describe node <node-ip-address>` for IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service or `oc describe node <node-ip-address>` for IBM Cloud Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud.
5. Run the Diagnostics and Debug Tool and the Openshift Diagnostics and Debug Tool. Export the kube and network test results to a compressed file and save the file to include in your support ticket. If all workers in your cluster are affected, you can skip this step as the debug tools cannot work properly if all worker nodes are disrupted.
6. Show that there are no added mutating or validating webhooks remaining in your cluster by getting the webhook details. Save the command output to include in your support ticket. Note that the following mutating webhooks might remain and do not need to be deleted: alertmanagerconfigs.openshift, managed-storage-validation-webhooks, multus.openshift.io, performance-addon-operator, prometheusrules.openshift.io,snapshot.storage.k8s.io.

Before opening a support ticket, it's recommended to review the information and follow any troubleshooting steps in the documents related to debugging worker nodes, worker node states, and troubleshooting worker nodes in Critical or NotReady state.

If only some of your worker nodes are affected, you must gather the relevant data to include in your support ticket. However, if all worker nodes in a cluster, or in a single zone, subnet, or VLAN are affected, you can open an initial support ticket without gathering data. You might later be asked to gather the relevant data.

Reference(s):
- IBM Cloud Kubernetes

rewritten_query: Please provide more details on how to use NodeSync in this context.
agent_response: NodeSync is a continuous repair service in DataStax Enterprise that automatically runs in the background to ensure that your data is in sync on all replicas, reducing the need for manual repairs. It is enabled by default on all key spaces and tables in Databases for DataStax to handle node repairs. You can also manually create tables with NodeSync enabled. Repairs issued against a NodeSync-enabled table are ignored. For more information on NodeSync, see the documentation on DataStax Enterprise NodeSync.

rewritten_query: How do I update a worker node?
agent_response:
A worker node is a machine that runs containerized tasks in a Kubernetes cluster. It can be a physical or virtual machine, and it is responsible for running pods, which are the smallest and simplest units in the Kubernetes object model that you create or deploy. Worker nodes are managed by the master node, which controls the worker nodes and assigns work to them.

To gather the relevant worker node data, follow these steps:

1. Check the conditions of your worker nodes and cluster before you gather data.
2. Check the CPU and memory level of your nodes. If any node is over 80% in either CPU or memory usage, consider provisioning more nodes or reducing your workload.
3. Gather information about your worker nodes by using the command `kubectl top node` (for IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service) or `oc top node` (for IBM Cloud Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud).
4. Save the output details to include in your support ticket. You can get the details of each node using the command `kubectl describe node <node-ip-address>` for IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service or `oc describe node <node-ip-address>` for IBM Cloud Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud.
5. Run the Diagnostics and Debug Tool and the Openshift Diagnostics and Debug Tool. Export the kube and network test results to a compressed file and save the file to include in your support ticket. If all workers in your cluster are affected, you can skip this step as the debug tools cannot work properly if all worker nodes are disrupted.
6. Show that there are no added mutating or validating webhooks remaining in your cluster by getting the webhook details. Save the command output to include in your support ticket. Note that the following mutating webhooks might remain and do not need to be deleted: alertmanagerconfigs.openshift, managed-storage-validation-webhooks, multus.openshift.io, performance-addon-operator, prometheusrules.openshift.io,snapshot.storage.k8s.io.

Before opening a support ticket, it's recommended to review the information and follow any troubleshooting steps in the documents related to debugging worker nodes, worker node states, and troubleshooting worker nodes in Critical or NotReady state.

How can i update a classic worker node?
To update a classic worker node, you can use the `ibmcloud ks worker update` command.

This command updates the classic worker node to the latest patch, and if a major.minor version update is also available, it updates the worker node to the same major.minor version as the master and latest patch version.

Here's an example command to update a worker node named `myworker` in the `mycluster` cluster:

```
ibmcloud ks worker update myworker --cluster mycluster
```

Keep in mind that your worker nodes can be only up to two versions behind the master version (n-2).
If you want to update the worker node to a specific patch version, you can use the `--patch-version` option followed by the desired patch version.
For more information, you can refer to the IBM Cloud documentation on [Update types](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-cs_versionsupdate_types).
It's also important to note that if you have apps running on worker nodes that you update, they may be rescheduled onto other worker nodes in the cluster.
To avoid downtime for your app, you must ensure that you have enough capacity in the cluster to carry the workload.
If you need to control how many worker nodes go down at a time during an update or reload, you can consider resizing your worker pool or adding stand-alone worker nodes to add more worker nodes.
You can remove the additional worker nodes after the update is completed.
If you encounter any issues during the update process, you can open a support ticket and include the relevant worker node information.

Remember that your worker nodes can only be one version behind the master version (n-1).
You can update the classic worker node to the same patch by using the `ibmcloud oc worker update` command.

Step 1: Update the cluster master

ibmcloud oc cluster master update --cluster CLUSTER [--version MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH] [--force-update] [-f] [-q]

Example command:

ibmcloud oc cluster master update --cluster mycluster --version 4.11.42 --force-update
2.
Wait until the master update finishes.

Red Hat OpenShift is available on various cloud providers, including IBM Cloud, and can be used to modernize traditional applications, build cloud-native applications, and manage machine learning and AI workloads. rewritten_query: What are the services of Virtual Network Functions?
agent_response: Virtual Network Functions (VNFs) are network services such as routers, firewalls, and load balancers that were traditionally run on proprietary hardware. With Network Function Virtualization (NFV), these services are packaged as virtual machines (VMs) on commodity hardware. This allows service providers to run their networks on standard servers instead of proprietary ones, which can be managed using the IBM Software-Defined Networking (SDN) controller for easy configuration, centralized management, and lower operational costs. The VNFs can be instantiated and modified without the need to deploy new network hardware, providing rapid service delivery and centralized policy control. The same routers, firewalls, load balancers, and VPNs used in physical hardware or other cloud providers can be used in IBM Cloud.

rewritten_query: Could you guide me on how to add the web chat widget?
agent_response:
To add a web chat widget to your website, you can follow these steps:

1. Go to the Integrations page and find the Web chat tile. Click on it to open the Web chat window.
2. Select the environment you want the web chat widget to connect to and click Confirm. This will open the Web chat page, where you can see the settings for the web chat integration in the selected environment.
3. Click on the Embed tab to generate a code snippet based on the web chat configuration. This code snippet will contain an HTML script element that calls JavaScript code hosted on an IBM site and creates an instance of a widget that communicates with the assistant.
4. Click the Copy icon to copy the embed script to the clipboard, and then paste it into the web page where you want the web chat to appear.

Keep in mind that no configuration changes are applied to the environment until you click Save and exit. You can also customize the appearance and behavior of the web chat before it is rendered by editing the configuration object in the embed script. For more information about the available configuration options, you can see [Configuration options object](https://web-chat.global.assistant.watson.cloud.ibm.com/docs.html?to=api-configurationconfigurationobject) in the web API reference.

Additionally, you can customize and extend the web chat by using the web chat API, and use a WebView to embed the web chat in your mobile app. For detailed reference information about the web chat API, see the web chat [developer documentation](https://web-chat.global.assistant.watson.cloud.ibm.com/docs.html?to=).

rewritten_query: How can I extend the web chat?
agent_response:
Yes, you can extend the capabilities of the web chat by using the Watson Assistant web chat toolkit on GitHub. If you choose to use the provided methods, you implement them by editing the code snippet that was generated earlier and then embed the updated code snippet into your web page. Here are some common tasks you can perform:

- Setting and passing context variable values
- Adding user identity information (if you don't enable security)

You can also further customize and extend the web chat by writing code and using the web chat API. For example, you can change how the web chat widget opens, show and hide content, and set identity information. Additionally, you can use a WebView with a JavaScript bridge to add the web chat to your mobile app. Detailed reference information about the web chat API can be found in the web chat developer documentation.

rewritten_query: Is web chat secure enough for passing sensitive data?
agent_response:
Yes, web chat security uses JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) which are data objects that are sent with each message from your website to the Watson Assistant service. These JWTs are digitally signed using a private encryption key that only you have, ensuring that each message originates with your website. The JWT payload can also be used to securely authenticate users and carry encrypted private data. However, if you need to pass sensitive data, it is recommended to encrypt it using the public key provided by IBM to add an additional level of encryption. For more information, see [Encrypting sensitive data](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/watson-assistant?topic=watson-assistant-web-chat-securityweb-chat-security-encrypt).

It is also important to note that before enabling security, you must create an RS256 public/private key pair and implement a function on your server that generates a JWT signed with your private key. This token will be used to verify the origin of messages sent from your website and optionally to carry additional encrypted data.

Additionally, make sure to keep your keys secure and never pass them to a client browser through your website. Detailed information about enabling web chat security can be found in the [Enabling web chat security](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/watson-assistant?topic=watson-assistant-web-chat-security-enable) document.
