rewritten_query: I want to modify the appearance of my web chat and how it operates when showing and hiding.
agent_response:
You can customize the appearance and behavior of your web chat widget by modifying the configuration object in the embed script. For example, you can change the colors used in the widget, specify an avatar image, and enable or disable the Built with IBM Watson watermark. To change how the web chat widget opens and closes, you can use the web chat API to hide the launcher icon, automatically start the widget in open state, or hide the close button.

You can find more information about customizing the web chat in the following resources:

* [Configuration options object](https://web-chat.global.assistant.watson.cloud.ibm.com/docs.html?to=api-configurationconfigurationobject) in the web API reference
* [Adding the web chat to your mobile application](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/watson-assistant?topic=watson-assistant-web-chat-develop-mobile)
* [Web chat developer documentation](https://web-chat.global.assistant.watson.cloud.ibm.com/docs.html?to=)

Additionally, you can use custom CSS classes to hide and show the main web chat window in response to the window:open and window:close events. For a tutorial and example code, see the [Custom elements for Watson Assistant web chat](https://github.com/watson-developer-cloud/assistant-toolkit/tree/master/integrations/webchat/examples/custom-element) example.

Is web chat secure enough for me to pass some sesitive data?
Yes, web chat security uses JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) which are data objects that are sent with each message from your website to the Watson Assistant service.
These JWTs are digitally signed using a private encryption key that only you have, ensuring that each message originates with your website.
The JWT payload can also be used to securely authenticate users and carry encrypted private data.
However, if you need to pass sensitive data, it is recommended to encrypt it using the public key provided by IBM to add an additional level of encryption.
For more information, see [Encrypting sensitive data](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/watson-assistant?topic=watson-assistant-web-chat-securityweb-chat-security-encrypt).
It is also important to note that before enabling security, you must create an RS256 public/private key pair and implement a function on your server that generates a JWT signed with your private key.
This token will be used to verify the origin of messages sent from your website and optionally to carry additional encrypted data.
Additionally, make sure to keep your keys secure and never pass them to a client browser through your website.

Detailed information about enabling web chat security can be found in the [Enabling web chat security](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/watson-assistant?topic=watson-assistant-web-chat-security-enable) document.

how to add web chat widget?

To add a web chat widget to your website, you can follow these steps:

1.
Go to the Integrations page and find the Web chat tile.
Click on it to open the Web chat window.
Select the environment you want the web chat widget to connect to and click Confirm.
This will open the Web chat page, where you can see the settings for the web chat integration in the selected environment.
Click on the Embed tab to generate a code snippet based on the web chat configuration.
This code snippet will contain an HTML script element that calls JavaScript code hosted on an IBM site and creates an instance of a widget that communicates with the assistant.
Click the Copy icon to copy the embed script to the clipboard, and then paste it into the web page where you want the web chat to appear.
Keep in mind that no configuration changes are applied to the environment until you click Save and exit.
You can also customize the appearance and behavior of the web chat before it is rendered by editing the configuration object in the embed script.

For more information about the available configuration options, you can see [Configuration options object](https://web-chat.global.assistant.watson.cloud.ibm.com/docs.html?to=api-configurationconfigurationobject) in the web API reference.
Additionally, you can customize and extend the web chat by using the web chat API, and use a WebView to embed the web chat in your mobile app.

rewritten_query: Could you explain how the web chat functionality works?
agent_response: The web chat is a chatbot interface that you can add to your website or mobile app without writing any code. It provides an easy-to-use platform for your customers to start conversations, ask questions, and perform tasks. The web chat uses the Watson Assistant v2 stateful API to communicate with the assistant and can be customized using JavaScript code and the web chat API. It supports a variety of devices and platforms, and complies with the Web Content Accessibility 2.1 Level AA standard for accessibility.

original_query: How does version 6.15.0 differ from 6.14.0?
rewritten_query: How does version 6.15.0 differ from 6.14.0?
agent_response: Version 6.15.0 of the IBM Cloud Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) command line interface (CLI) introduces new commands image-obsolete and image-deprecate for image lifecycle management. Additionally, image lifecycle management has been added to image-create, image-update, and images commands. On the other hand, version 6.14.0 has no new commands, but it adds support for more algorithms in the SSH key key-create command. The notes section for version 6.14.1 mentions a fix for an issue with using the SSH key generated from the UI in the CLI. However, there are no other differences mentioned or documented between these two versions in the provided document.

rewritten_query: How do I use the image-obsolete and image-deprecate commands for image lifecycle management?
agent_response:
To use the new `image-obsolete` and `image-deprecate` commands introduced in version 6.15.0 of the IBM Cloud Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) command line interface (CLI), you can follow the examples below:

* Change the image lifecycle status to deprecated:

  `ibmcloud is image-deprecate IMAGE`

  Replace `IMAGE` with the name or ID of the custom image you want to deprecate.

* Change the image lifecycle status to obsolete:

  `ibmcloud is image-obsolete IMAGE`

  Replace `IMAGE` with the name or ID of the custom image you want to obsolete.

It's important to note that these commands can only be used to schedule a status change for a future date and time, or to make an immediate status change if no future status change is scheduled. To remove a scheduled status change, see [Remove a scheduled custom image lifecycle status change by using the CLI](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/vpc?topic=vpc-managing-custom-imagesschedule-reset-ilm-status-change-cli). After you remove the scheduled status change, you can make an immediate status change.

If you want to schedule the status change for a future date and time, you can use the `--deprecate-at` or `--obsolete-at` option with the `ibmcloud is image-update` command and specify a date in the ISO 8601 (YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss+hh:mm) date and time format.

For example, to schedule the image to be deprecated on a specific date and time:

`ibmcloud is image-update IMAGE --deprecate-at YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss+hh:mm`

Replace `IMAGE` with the name or ID of the custom image you want to update, and replace `YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss+hh:mm` with the date and time you want to schedule the deprecation for.

You can also schedule the image to be obsolete at a specific date and time using the `--obsolete-at` option with the `ibmcloud is image

Once you have the dates, you can use the `ibmcloud is image-update` command with the `--obsolete-at` or `--deprecate-at` option to schedule the status change for the desired dates. `ibmcloud is image-update IMAGE --deprecate-at YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss+hh:mm`

Replace `IMAGE` with the name or ID of the custom image you want to update, and replace `YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss+hh:mm` with the date and time you want to schedule the deprecation for.

To schedule the image to be obsolete in one month:
`ibmcloud is image-update IMAGE --obsolete-at YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss+hh:mm`

Replace `IMAGE` with the name or ID of the custom image you want to update, and replace `YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss+hh:mm` with the date and time you want to schedule the obsolescence for.

rewritten_query: What examples of words representing disgust can Watson Assistant detect?
agent_response:
The Emotion Analysis feature of Watson Assistant can detect emotions in text, including the emotion of "disgust." However, the documents do not provide a specific list of words that it can detect to indicate disgust. The system calculates a score for each emotion (anger, disgust, fear, joy, sadness) on a scale of 0.0 to 1.0. If the score of any emotion is 0.5 or higher, then that emotion is detected. The higher the score above 0.5, the higher the relevance.

For example, in the provided snippet of a document enriched with Emotion Analysis, the emotion of "disgust" has a score of 0.102578. This score is below the 0.5 threshold, so Watson did not detect "disgust" in this particular text.

If you want to improve the detection of disgust in your text, you can train the system with examples that contain words or phrases associated with this emotion. Additionally, you can enable fuzzy matching if you think your customers may not use the appropriate accents or may misspell words.

I apologize if my previous response did not fully meet your expectations. I can certainly try to provide examples of words that might indicate disgust in a text. That being said, here are some examples of words or phrases that might indicate disgust in a text:

* "disgusting"
* "revolting"
* "nauseating"
* "repulsive"
* "gross"
* "vile"
* "loathsome"
* "filthy"
* "putrid"
* "foul"

Again, the Emotion Analysis feature takes into account the broader context of the text to detect emotions, so the presence of these words alone is not a guarantee that the emotion of "disgust" will be detected.

original_query: VPC
extracted_sentences: How do cloud computing security protocols evolve over time, and what are the potential implications for restoring volumes from backup snapshots in IBM Cloud VPC?
The documents provided do not contain information on how cloud computing security protocols evolve over time.
However, they do provide information on restoring volumes from backup snapshots in IBM Cloud VPC.
Restoring a volume from a backup snapshot in IBM Cloud VPC creates a new, fully provisioned boot or data volume.
This process can be done during instance creation, instance modification, or when you provision a new stand-alone volume.
For data volumes, you can also use the volumes API to create a data volume from a snapshot.
For best performance, you can enable snapshots for fast restore.
This feature allows you to create a volume from a snapshot that is fully provisioned when the volume is created.

It's important to note that restoring a volume from a backup snapshot may result in degraded performance in the beginning, as the data is copied from IBM Cloud Object Storage to Block Storage for VPC.
You can also copy a backup snapshot from one region to another region for disaster recovery scenarios.
The cross-regional copy can be used to turn on your virtual server instance and data volumes in a different region.

The fast restore feature allows you to cache snapshots in a specified zone of your choosing, which enables volumes to be restored from snapshots nearly immediately and the new volumes to operate with full IOPS instantly.
When using fast restore, the data is pulled from a cached backup snapshot in another zone of your VPC.

agent_response: A Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) provides network isolation and security in the IBM Cloud. A VPC can be a building block that encapsulates a corporate division (marketing, development, accounting, ...) or a collection of microservices owned by a DevSecOps team. VPCs can be connected to an on-premises enterprise and each other. This may create the need to route traffic through centralized firewall-gateway appliances. IBM provides tutorials and documentation to guide users in implementing a hub and spoke architecture and connecting locations using Direct Link. The VPC's networking is isolated at the hypervisor, network, and router levels, using virtual network identifiers (VNIs) and the implicit routing function to ensure secure and efficient communication between virtual server instances. IBM VPC also offers features such as fast restore, backup snapshots, and data encryption for added data protection and performance.

original_query: What are the billing plans available and differences between each of them?
rewritten_query: What are the billing plans available and differences between each of them?
agent_response:
Based on the provided documents, the billing plans available are Subscription and Enterprise Savings Plan. Here are the differences between them:

1. Monthly Billing: Subscription accounts are billed monthly based on consumption, while Enterprise Savings Plan accounts are billed timely, independent of usage.

2. Invoicing: Subscription accounts are invoiced on monthly consumption, while Enterprise Savings Plan accounts are invoiced on monthly consumption as well, but the invoices are not adjusted based on usage.

3. Best Suited For: Subscription accounts are best suited for developers and companies, while Enterprise Savings Plan accounts are best suited for enterprise organizations.

4. Cost Estimation: Subscription accounts provide a 10% discount on usage costs for a yearly spending commitment, while Enterprise Savings Plan accounts offer similar benefits with added advantages.

5. Fixed Billing: Subscription accounts offer a fixed billing amount for the subscription period, while Enterprise Savings Plan accounts also provide fixed billing for financial planning.

Additionally, the document mentions that with an IBM Cloud billable account, you're charged for the compute, containers, and services that your organization consumes. The charging types include Fixed (based on an agreed upon monthly charge), Metered (based on the number of GB hours for runtimes and the number of IP addresses and storage for containers), and Tiered (based on a tiered pricing model with volume-based discounts).

how can I estimate my costs?
To estimate your costs in IBM Cloud, you can use the cost estimator tool.

Here are the steps to follow:

1.
Go to the IBM Cloud console and click on the Cost estimator icon.
Click on 'Create new estimate' and enter a name and description for your estimate.
Click 'Create' and you will be directed to the estimate details page.
Click on 'Go to catalog' to add products to the estimate.
Select the product that you are interested in and click 'Add to estimate'.
Enter your estimated usage and click 'Calculate Cost'.
Keep in mind that some charges, such as costs for your underlying infrastructure, may not be reflected in the estimate.
Also, if you need to estimate costs for a different location or currency, you may need to select the appropriate currency on the order summary page or change the currency on your account.
Additionally, when you create a resource like a location or cluster, you can review a cost estimate in the Summary pane of the console.
You can also view and control your current usage by visiting the relevant IBM Cloud documentation.
are there different types of charges I am charged?

Furthermore, the [Estimating your costs](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/billing-usage?topic=billing-usage-costcost) documentation offers guidance on estimating costs for different types of services and resources.
In general, it's essential to understand your usage patterns and the pricing structure of the specific services you are utilizing to ensure accurate cost estimation and control.

Fixed: Fixed-rate pricing is based on an agreed-upon monthly charge that isn't adjusted, regardless of usage.

rewritten_query: I'd like to change my pricing plan and check my usage.
agent_response:
To update your pricing plan, you need to open a support case as mentioned in the provided document. Here are the steps to follow:

1. Click the Help icon in the console menu bar.
2. Click Create a case.
3. Select Account > Partner Center - Sell. Then, select Partner Center - Sell Price Change as the subtopic.
4. Click Next.
5. Enter a case subject line following this format: Your product name Price Change Request.
6. Provide the following details in the case description:
   - Service ID
   - Plan IDs
   - Intended Delivery Date
   - Link to Partner Center Entry
   - Metric ID
   - Price Change To
7. Click Next.
8. Review your case summary, and click Submit case.

After submitting your support case, you must email the onboarding specialists at [cloud.onboarding@ibm.com](mailto:cloud.onboarding@ibm.com) to help draft a 30-day notice of any price changes.

To view your usage, you can go to Manage > Billing and usage in the IBM Cloud console if you own one of the following accounts:

* New and existing Pay-As-You-Go accounts based in the US with any payment method other than a credit card
* New and existing Pay-As-You-Go accounts not based in the US
* New and existing Subscription accounts worldwide

If you are a new Pay-As-You-Go account owner located in the US and paying with a credit card, you can manage your credit card from the Payments page in the IBM Cloud console. However, updating a credit card requires a manual review that might take a few days to process. To view your open change request cases, go to IBM Cloud Support.

You might manage your payment method on a separate billing platform. You can easily register, update, or delete a payment method by going to IBM Billing.
